"If the patient is already weakened or has another illness in addition to Hydropism, then as it would be if he were a sieve with water flowing through him; so that when he drinks, either of these things will happen: either his strength will return and he'll get better, or on the contrary, his condition will deteriorate further. But if you give him iron at this time, because of fear for what might come to pass.
Si autem uides infirmum exuberantis uirtutis, neque est cum eo aegritudo praeter Hydropisim solam: et non est puer, neque senex: tunc modus operationis in eo est, ut tu eleues infirmum stantem inter manus tuas, et minister post ipsum exprimat uentrem eius manu sua impellendo aquam ad inferiorem partem pectinis.	 "If you notice a patient who is already very weak and has no other ailment besides Hydropism, it's not that he is getting worse due to the additional affliction; nor yet an infant or old person: so at this point in his condition there must be a mode of treatment which I will tell you now. You shall draw him into your hands as if you were holding out one hand and supporting him with the other, then pour water gently down his throat from above downwards.
Deinde accipe spatumile spinosum, secundum hanc formam.	 "Afterwards take it slowly and carefully by this way.
Sit duarum partium acutarum, longum, acutae extremitatis sicut Spatumile.	 The two parts are acute, long, and narrow like a sieve.
Verumtamen in eo sit quiddam breuitatis paulatim, ut non pertranseas cum eo apud operationem usque ad intestinum, et laedas ipsum.	 "However there must be some slight weakness present so that you won't pass through it until the operation is complete and afterwards.
Deinde considera.	 Afterwards consider
Nam si est generatio Hydropisis ex parte intestinorum, tunc oportet ut elongeris cum sectione ab umbilico quantitate trium digitorum, ad inferiora in directo eius supra pectinem.	 "If the generation of Hydropism comes from a part of the intestines, then you must extend it with three fingers' length upwards and downwards above his throat.
Si uero generatio Hydropisis est propter aegritudinem epatis: tunc sit sectio tua sinistra ab umbilico tribus digitis.	 "If the generation of Hydropism comes due to exhaustion from outside, then you must make a section with your left hand and extend it three fingers upwards.
Et si generatio eius est propter splenem, tunc sit sectio in latere dextro: et non oportet etiam ut sit sectio in latere super quod uult iacere infirmus, ut non currant superfluitates ad illum locum debilem.	 "And if the generation of him is due to weakness on one side, then you must make a section in the right side and do not let there be made another cut into the weakened place lest it flows out more than needed.
Deinde perfora cum instrumento cutem totam.	 "Then make an incision with your whole instrument.
Deinde intromitte in illam sectionem, et eleua manum tuam cum Spatumili inter cutem, et sifac, quasi tu excories ipsum: et sit quantitas quae excoriatur quantitas unguis, aut circiter ilud.	 "Then insert into the incision and take your thumb with a sieve between the incision, and push it gently as if you were squeezing him; and let there be applied the quantity of that which is being removed equal to the length of a finger or in such manner around.
Deinde perfora sifac, donec perueniat Spatumile ad locum uacuum: et est locus aquae.	 "Then pierce the vein, let it run out into space until there is a vacuum; and that spot will be water.
Deinde extrahe ipsum, et intromitte in foramen instrumentum, cuius haec est forma.	 "After piercing, remove it out and put [it] into the opening/foramen of an instrument whose shape this is.
Et est simile cannulae: fit ex argento, aut aere, aut aurichalco, lene, tersum: cui in inferiori parte sui est foramen paruum, et in lateribus eius sunt tria foramina, duo ab una parte, et unum a parte altera: et facia est extremitas eius incisa, secundum modum incisionis calami, sicut uides: in extremitate eius superiore est armilla.	 "And it is similar to a tube of metal or air or ear trumpet; there are three openings on the side opposite from where the vein comes out and two on each side near that opening/foramen, one at an angle to the other - thus its end was cut off in the manner of a razor blade as you see: above it is a ring.
Nam quando instrumentum peruenit ad aquam, tunc ipsa descendit statim super instrumentum, ergo euacua ex aqua in hora quantitatem mediam.	 "When the instrument pierces through to water then that water descends immediately over/upon the instrument; therefore half a measure of water is extracted at once.
Quoniam si tu euacuas ex ea plus quam oportet, in hora fortasse moritur infirmus per resolutionem spiritus sui animalis: aut accidit ei syncopis quae appropinquat morti.	 "If the water is extracted from it more than necessary then either the sick person will die at once through a failure of his vital spirits, or he will have convulsions which approach death.
Verum euacua ex ea secundum quantitatem uirtutis eius, et secundum quod significant tibi dispositiones infirmi ex uirtute pulsus eius, et ex bonitate eius.	 "Indeed the water is extracted from it according to its power and how much strength he has; also considering that you know his dispositions when you feel his pulse with kindness.
Deinde extrahe instrumentum, et retine aquam.	 "After removing the instrument hold onto/retain the water.
Quod est, quia retinetur statim propter cutem quae retinet foramen quod est super sifac: de quo narraui, ut perfores ipsum secundum illum modum.	 "This is because you must hold onto/retain it quickly due to the cut that retains the vein where it comes out; from which I will tell you how to pierce it in that manner.
Deinde itera instrumentum die altero, si uides infirmum tolerare illud: et extrahe etiam ex aqua quantitatem paruam.	 "The following day if you are able to tolerate the instrument then remove and also extract half a measure of water.
Fac illud diebus aliquot sine timore, et custodi te ab errore: donec non remaneat ex aqua nisi parum.	 "Do this on several days without fear or worry until all but half the water is not left over/remaining from the water.
Si autem times super infirmum, et dimittis ex aqua rem multam: tunc cura ipsum cum sepultura in harena calida, et sudore multo in balneo et sole, et expectet super sitim: et cura ipsum cum medicinis exiccatiuis, donec sanetur: et cauteriza super stomachum, et epar, et splenem, post extractionem aquae: secundum quod narraui in eo quod praecessit.	 "If the sick person is worse and you have removed a large amount of water then care for him with cold water baths, sweat much on hot days, expectorate from his chest, wash over/upon him [with] wet clothes after removing it; according to what I told you in that instrument.
¶ De cura infantium qui nascuntur locis urinae eorum non perforatis.	 The care of infants born in a place where they are not pierced
Caput LV.	 head
Quando egreditur aliquis infantium ex uentre matris suae, et caput mutonis eius est non perforatum, aut est foramen strictum, aut in non suo loco.	 When I examine a newborn infant from its mother's womb, and the child's head is not pierced (or has a narrow or blocked hole), either because it was not born through the birth canal, or there is something wrong with that place
Oportet ergo succurrere cum perforatione eius statim cum nascitur cum Spatumili subtili ualde, secundum hanc formam.	 Therefore I suggest to apply a small piece of wire (sputumuli) immediately upon birth in order to remove any obstruction and ensure smooth passage.
Deinde pone in foramine clauum subtilem ex plumbo, et liga ipsum: et tene ipsum tribus diebus, aut quatuor.	 Then place a small clamp made from lead (cluum), bind it tightly, hold it in place for three days or four.
Quando ergo uult urinam emittere, remoueatur, et mingat.	 After urination is emitted, remove the clot and urine remains.
Deinde reduc ipsum.	 Then release him.
Et si tu non ponis plumbum, iam possibile est, ut urina quae incedit super locum, non permittat ipsum claudi.	 If you don't put lead, it is still possible for the urine that flows over the place not to allow the clot to form.
Ille autem cuius foramen est strictum, medicatur cum plumbo, sicut diximus, diebus multis, donec amplificetur.	 The one whose hole is narrow must be treated with lead as we described, for many days until it becomes wider.
Illi autem in quibus est foramen in non suo loco, laeduntur.	 Those who have the hole not at their place are to be treated.
Quod est, quia ex eis qui nascitur, foramen est apud finem capitis uirgae: quare non potest mingere ad anteriora, donec eleuat uirgam manu sua ad superiora.	 That is because when they are born the hole of their head ends in the neck of the veins (or in some sources, the hole ends at the top of the neck). And so it cannot empty itself to its own, until it has released the hand with its own towards its upper side.
Neque est ei generatio, propterea, quod sperma non potest peruenire ad matricem secundum rectitudinem: et est aegritudo foeda ualde.	 Neither is generation there, because semen cannot penetrate into the mother's body in accordance with nature; and therefore, there is foetal distress from lead.
Et modus operationis in illo est, ut resupinetur infirmus super dorsum suum.	 And the way of treatment/operation in this case is to support his back up
Deinde extende caput uirgae eius manu tua sinistra extensione uehementi, et incide caput capitis uirgae ex loco priapi, cum acumine, aut spatumili acuto: sicut est incisio calami, aut sicut tu radis aliquid, ut medium eius ueniat simile capiti uirgae: et ut cadat foramen in medio secundum quod oportet.	 Then extend his head towards the left hand of you and cut off the top of veins from its place by a sharp tool (sutumuli or spatumili), so as to remove obstruction, ensuring smooth passage like an incision with a knife would do, except this is done with the fingers rather than a blade. And then bring it to the middle in accordance with what is appropriate.
Et caue tibi apud operationem tuam a fluxu sanguinis.	 It's important that you are there at the time of his blood flow
Multotiens enim accidit illud.	 "Many times does it happen that this occurs.
Oppone ergo ei cum eo quod abscindit sanguinem, et cura uulnus, donec sanetur.	 Therefore, if he cuts through the artery with his instrument and causes a wound to bleed out, until he is cured.
¶ De Albather quae accidunt in praeputio et capite uigae, et corruptione, nigredine, et adhaerentia.	 The things that occur through the instrument and the cutting of the vein, corruption, negligence, and the letting go.
Caput LVI.	 Section VI.
Multotiens accidunt istae Albather in uirga, et est eminentia carnis foedae.	 Many times occur these things to Albucasis with the instrument, and a great swelling of the muscle occurs.
Et ex ea alia est maligna, et alia non maligna.	 And from this other things are bad as well as good.
Non malignam ergo oportet ut suspendas cum uncino subtili, et abscindas eam, donec mundes eam totam.	 Therefore it is necessary to suspend with a subtle hook and let go of her, until all the world has taken her entirely.
Deinde pone super eam cotum submersum in unguento aegyptio.	 Then he puts himself under an Egyptian ointment on top of her.
Deinde cura ipsum post illud cum unguento dyafinicon, donec sanetur.	 Therefore the care is with him after this thing and the ointment for healing, until he is cured.
Quod si Albather est maligna, foedi coloris, tunc oportet ut administres in ea cauterium post incisionem eius et ipsius rasionem.	 If Albucasis is bad as a color, then it is necessary that you administer to her cautery after the cutting of his and hers reasons.
Si autem Albather est in praeputio captiui, non circumcisi, et est pars Albather inter praeputium, et pars eius extra: tunc oportet ut auferas Albather, quae est intus in primis, donec quando consolidatur, tunc cura ipsum exterius: quoniam quando tu curas eam simul, non securatur praeputium quin preforetur.	 If Albucasis is captured through the instrument and is not circumcised, then a part of Albucasis between capture and another part outside it is necessary that you take Albucasis who is inside first until he consolidates; thereafter care for him externally because when you cure her simultaneously, it does not secure the capture which precedes.
Et iam accidunt etiam in testiculis, et praeputio nigredo et corruptio.	 And also occur these things to Albucasis on testicles as well, and corruption occurs from capture and negligence
Oportet ergo, ut tu concaues totum quod iam denigratum est, et quod uult corrumpi, aut iam corruptum est.	 Therefore it is necessary that you tie up everything which has already been corrupted as well as what he wants to corrupt or is already corrupted.
Deinde line super ipsum post illud cum melle quod iam concussum est cum farina corticum granatorum, et herbi tritorum cribellatorum.	 Then you put a line on top of him after this with the earth which has been tied up previously with flour for grinding grains and herbs as well as threshing weeds.
Deinde cura illud cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	 Therefore care is with it along with the remaining care until he is cured.
Si autem accidat fluxus sanguinis, tunc administra cauterium cum cauterio lunari, secundum hanc formam.	 If Albucasis cuts through an artery then administer cautery together with lunar cautery in this manner.
Cauterium enim est iuuatiuum ad duas dispositiones simul, scilicet ad fluxum sanguinis, et uulnus quando corrumpitur.	 Cautery is a tool used in two different ways simultaneously, one being to control bleeding and the other when a wound becomes infected
Quod si corroditur caput uirgae, et destruitur totum in hora: tunc oportet ut intromittas in meatum priapi cannulam ex plumbo, ut mingat infirmus super eam.	 If the head is pierced by a sword and destroyed completely at once, then you must immediately apply pressure to the wound with a clamp from a lead weight so that it may be held firmly against her.
In adhaerentia uero praeputii cum capite uirgae, et haec quidem adhaerentia non accidit, nisi in eo cuius praeputium est sanum, et non exigitur super ipsum circumcisio: et quandoque accidit adhaerentia propter uulnus, aut apostema: oportet ergo ut excories eam cum Spatumili obtuso, donec soluatur ligamentum, et liberetur caput uirgae ab omni parte.	 If the blow struck on the head or upper part of the body and did not result in death (as it would if a fatal blow), unless the victim was wearing armor that protected him from such an injury; then when this happens, you must immediately apply pressure to the wound with a thumb cramp from iron, so as to hold it firmly against her.  If the blow struck on the lower part of the body or the hand and did not result in death (as it would if a fatal blow), unless the victim was wearing armor that protected him from such an injury; then when this happens, you must first apply pressure with your thumb cramp to hold it closed against her.
Quod si est difficile discernere ea exquisite, tunc oportet ut excories aliquid ex capite uirgae, et ex praeputio.	 If discerning who struck the blow is difficult due to the head being covered or obscured in some way, then you must apply pressure with your thumb cramp on the hand from the shield side, as well as against her head/face.
Quod est, quia praeputium quando est subtile, fortasse perforatur propter subtilitatem suam uelociter.	 This is because when someone wields a sword with great subtlety, there's a risk they may inadvertently strike the opponent in such a way that it pierces their armor or strikes a weak point of the body
Deinde separa inter praeputium, et caput uirgae cum panno lini subtili, qui iam madefactus est in aqua frigida, ut non adhereant iterum.	 Afterwards remove both your thumb cramp from the shield and the hand from the face with a linen bandage soaked in cold water so that they don't stick to each other anymore.
Deinde curetur cum uino stiptico, donec consolidetur.	 After this you will treat him with wine or some other beverage until he regains consciousness.
¶ De mundificatione infantium, et curatione ex errore eis accidente.	 For the sake of education and the care of them so that they don't make mistakes.
Caput LVII.	 Title 72
Circumcisio non est solutio continuitatis, sicut reliqua uulnera: uerumtamen cum sit ex operatione nostra, uoluntate nostra, et usus eius sit in pueris proprie, est necesse ut signemus in ea operationem meliorem, et uiam leuiorem perducentem ad salutem.	 Circumcision is not a solution to continuality like other wounds; however since it comes from our own action and use, they wish that we teach them how this procedure can be done better and safer so as to save their lives.
Dico ergo, quod antiqui non dixerunt circumcisionem in aliquo suorum librorum: quoniam non utuntur in legibus suis, et non est nisi quod acquisiuimus per experimentum.	 Therefore I say that ancient authors did not write about circumcision in any of their books; because it is not used according to their laws and is only something we have acquired through experience.
Quod est, quia ego inueni maiorem partem artificum, et phlebotomatorum uti mundificatione, circumcidendo cum nouacula, et cum forficibus: et utuntur alfecati, et ligaudo cum filo, et incisione cum ungula.	 To cut is because I have made the greater part of my art and phlebotomists' work more effective by making incisions with a blade or other instrument around a wound while holding it closed with forceps; so that they are opened up, ligated with thread, and incised with a knife.
Et ego quidem iam probaui omnes istos modos, et non inueni meliorem mundificatione cum forficibus, et ligamento cum filo.	 And I have also tested all these methods but was not able to improve the work of phlebotomists more effectively with forceps and thread ligation.
Quoniam in mundificatione cum nouacula, multotiens effugit cutis.	 Because when making incisions around a wound while holding it closed with a blade or other instrument, too much skin was removed.
Quoniam cutis praeputii duas habet tunicas: ergo forsitan inciditur cutis superior, et temanet tunica inferior: cogitur ergo ad incisionem ad incidendum alteram, et dolorem futurum.	 There are two layers of skin; therefore one must make a transverse incision into the upper layer and leave the lower layer intact so that an additional incision can be made for further treatment and future pain.
Et cum mundificatione quae fit per alfecati, id est, digitalis, quo utuntur sutores, non securatur incisio extremitatis uirilis membri: quoniam fortasse ingreditur in foramen eius.	 And when making incisions with the aid of fingerstiffs (also called suture needles), that is to say, those used by surgeons, it is not ensured that the incision at the end of the wrist will be made without injury; for fear may occur from piercing its hole.
In mundificatione autem cum ungula, fortasse euadit ferrum, et corrumpit operationem tuam: et cutis quidem pueri est breuis natura, et multotiens nascuntur taliter, quod non indigent mundificatione: et iam uidi illud.	 However when making incisions with a knife (or other instruments like scalpels), there is sometimes the risk of staining your operation and causing children's skin to become pale due to its nature, which often leads to such injuries; I have already heard about this occurrence.
Mundificationis autem cum forficibus, et ligamento cum filo, bonum experimentum detexit mihi: quoniam forfices sunt proportionalis incisionis: propterea, quod acuitas quae est superius, est sicut acuitas quae est inferius.	 The experiments with forceps and thread were good for me as the incisions made by them are proportional; therefore because the higher acuity is like that of the lower acuity.
Cum ergo premis manum tuam, proportionantur duae acuitates, et incidunt secundum operationem unam in tempore uno: et fit compressio simili figura, continens cutem uirgae ab omni parte, cum qua non cadit error omnino.	 Therefore when you use both hands to make the incision and they are proportioned according to one operation at a time; and there is made a similar compression that holds back the skin from all sides while no mistake occurs in any part of it.
Et modus operationis propriae est, ut facias extimare, puerum praecipue, si est ex eis qui intelligunt parumper, quod tu non facis, nisi quod ligas filum in uirga sua tantum: et dimittas ipsum usque ad diem alium.	 The method of the operation itself is as follows; to extimate the boy especially if you can learn from those who are more skilled than you, that is unless you ligate thread only into its own hole and then release it until another day.
Deinde fac eum gaudere et laetari omnimodo quo possibile est tibi illud, ex eo quod recipit intelligentia sua.	 Then make him enjoy life in all ways possible through what he has received from his intelligence.
Deinde fac eum stare inter manus tuas praeparatae staturae, et non sit sedens: et occulta forfices in manica tua, aut sub pede tuo, ne uideat eos puer omnino, neque aliquid ex instrumentis.	 "Then place it between your raised hands and let it not lie down; secretly open the fingers of your hand or under your foot so that no one else may see them, except by means of an instrument.
Deinde intromitte manum tuam ad uirgam eius, et suffla in cutem, et trahe eam sursum, donec egrediatur caput uirgae.	 "Then take hold of his arm with your hand and apply the bandage around it tightly so that when you pull him up he will be freed from the wound.
Deinde mundifica ipsam ex eo quod aggregatur in ea sordicie.	 "Then cleanse the same thing which has been collected into this bandage by means of a tube (lit., 'sordice' - a small, thin tube).
Deinde liga locum signatum cum filo duplo.	 "Then tie it with double cord.
Postea liga inferius eo parumper ligamentum secundum.	 "Then tighten the lower part of it more than its upper part.
Deinde tene cum indice tuo, et pollice locum ligamenti inferioris retentione bona, et incide inter duo ligamenta.	 "Hold on with your thumb and forefinger; secure the lower ligature firmly while holding both ends of it tightly together in between.
Deinde eleua cutem sursum uelociter, et extrahe caput uirgae.	 "Then apply pressure to the wound or you may lift him up by his arm and out of the bandage.
Deinde dimitte sanguinem currere paulatim (est enim melius) et pone puluerem desuper: et super puluerem pannum in quo expansus est uitellus oui decocti in aqua rosata, concussum cum oleo ros recenti bono: et dimitte eum super ipsum usque ad diem alium: et cura ipsum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	 "Then gently run the blood for a short time and remove some of the excess fat; cover it with another bandage which has been soaked in boiled water, vinegar, and oil, and secure this bandaged part to that above it until you are free from care.
Forma autem forficis ad mundificationem haec est.	 "The shape is formed so as to facilitate the cleansing of these things which have been collected into a bandage by means of tubes (lit., 'sordice' - a small, thin tube).
Sint hebetes duae extremitates, et sint incidentes: ne egrediatur in eis ramus claui: et sit longitudo duarum acuitatum, sicut longitudo duorum manubriorum aequaliter.	 "There should be two fingers and they are bent; so that the length of both of them may be equal to the length of their corresponding hands.
Error uero cadens in mundificatione est: quoniam fortasse effugit cutis intrinseca tota, aut pars eius apud incisionem.	 "A mistake occurs during the cleansing when some skin is torn off completely or a part of it at the incision.
Ergo oportet, ut extendas eam ex hora tua cum ungue tuo ante apostemationem loci: et incidas eam secundum aequalitatem.	 "Therefore you should push her out when your thumb is on and before the application of the ligature; cut it off in equal parts.
Quod si non potes tenere eam cum ungue tuo, tunc extrahe eam cum uncino, et incide eam.	 "If you are unable to hold her with your thumb, then pull her out quickly using a finger and cut it off.
Si autem praeterierint ei tres dies, et remanet quod est sub uirga inflatum, apostematum: tunc dimitte illud, donec sedetur apostema calidum, et excoria illud cum facilitate, et incide illud secundum quod praeparatur tibi: et caue tibi a capite uirgae.	 "If three days have passed and there is still swelling under the bandage; then release it so that cold may come upon the wound, loosen it gently with oil and cut it off in accordance to what has been prepared for you.
Non enim nocebit ei illud.	 "It shall not harm him.
Cura ergo illud cum eo quod consolidat uulnus ex pulueribus, quos narrauimus in tractatu de pulueribus: et si inciditur ex cute supra mensuram, et euadit ad superiora, non nocet ei illud etiam.	 "Therefore let the surgeon proceed with him as he heals a wound inflicted by cutting above the line of measurement, and let it go to the top if the cut is made that way; but still do not harm him.
Cura ergo illud cum eo quod diximus, donec sanetur.	 "Therefore proceed with him as you said, until he is healed.
¶ De extractione Vrinae retentae in uesica.	 "Of the retained urine in the bladder.
Caput LVIII.	 Eighty-eighth head.
Urinae retentio in uesica, fit ab opilatione facta ex lapide, aut sanguine congelato, aut pus, aut carne nata, et similibus illis ex eis quae diximus ex modis curationis in diuisione.	 Retention of urine in the bladder is treated by removal from stone, or cold blood, or pus, or formed flesh; and just as you have provided remedies for these methods of curing in another part
Et si non soluitur Vrina, et uides retentionem eius esse propter Lapidem, qui iam est in collo uesicae: tunc oportet ut sit infirmus super genua sua curuatus.	 And if the bladder stone cannot be removed and you believe that his retention is caused by it, then he should lie down on his knees to cure him.
Deinde componantur pedes eius super dorsum eius, et extendat uentrem suum ex superiori parte dorsi eius, et stringat infirmus anhelitum suum quantum possibile est ei.	 Then both of his feet should be placed on his back and the upper part of his back should be stretched out to stretch as much as possible his longing for healing.
Cogitur ergo cum collo uesicae ad expulsionem Lapidis ad posteriora: quare absoluitur Vrina.	 He will then proceed with the bladder stone towards its removal from behind, because the retention was resolved.
Quod si non soluitur cum eo quod diximus, et uehemens sit res super infirmum: tunc oportet ut administres extractionem eius cum instrumento, quod nominatur siringa, cuius haec est forma Sit ex argento, et sit subtile, lene, concauum sicut cannula pennae auis in subtilitate radii, longum in similitudine palmi unius et medii: cui sit cannula subtilis in capite eius.	 If not resolved as he had said and the bladder stone is still a problem for him, then you should proceed to administer its removal with an instrument called siringa, which has this form; it is long like a pen's tube but slenderer than one palm, smooth, and made of such fine steel that needles could be drawn from it.
Et modus exitus Vrinae per ipsum est, ut accipias filum duplicatum, et liges in extremitate eius lanam, aut cotum, ligatura bona: et intromittas extremitatem fili in inferiori parte Siringae: et incide cum forficibus si superfluit aliquid ex lana, uerum intromitte in cannulam cum uehementia, sicut alzer.	 The mode of exiting the bladder through him is like taking hold of a double thread and tightening it at both ends to make a knot; then inserting one end into an inferior part of the siringa and cutting off with fingers if anything comes from the wool as you would do when you are weaving, but you should put it in the cannula just as before.
Deinde inunge siringam cum oleo, aut cum butyro, et albugine oui: et fac sedere infirmum super sedem, et embroca uesicam, et ipsius uirgam cum oleis humidis, et oleo oliuae, et aqua tepida.	 Then with oil or butter and white wax; make the bed of the patient comfortable, and bind up his bladder; then you should wash him with olive oil from above downward, or with butter, or with almond water; warm the water gently.
Deinde intromitte siringam in uirgam cum facilitate, donec perueniat ad radicem uirgae.	 "Next, place the instrument gently on top of the vein with ease and let it pierce its root.
Deinde dupla ipsam superius a parte umbilici.	 "Place both ends on either side of the vein
Deinde impelle siringam intra ipsam, donec perueniat ad Vesicam, et sentiat eam infirmus iam peruenisse ad rem uacuam: et non fit hoc secundum hunc ordinem, nisi quoniam meatus, in quo uadit, est in quo est tortuositas.	 "Next, press the instrument firmly into the vein so it pierces its root and feels for the artery, and if found, gently guides it to this, aiming at the matter, which is not according to this order unless there is a special reason why that particular point is good because it has a lot of tortuousness.
Deinde extende filum cum lana paulatim.	 "Finally spread out the thread with gentle care
Vrina enim sequetur lanam.	 "The vein follows the thread.
Deinde extrahe eam, et fac currere Vrinam per uiam urinae: et itera siringam, et non cesses facere illud, donec euacuetur uesica, et inueniat infirmus alleuiationem.	 "Next remove the vein and lead it through a narrow channel for hunting (hunting the arrow), repeating this until you have found the vein and let the instrument gently pierce its vein.
¶ De qualitate clisterizationis uesicae cum Clepshydra.	 "The quality of the instrument must be tested with the clepsydra
Caput LIX.	 "The head of 39.
Quando accidit in uesica ulcus, aut sanguis in ea congelatur, aut coartatur in ea pus, et uis distillare in eam aquas et medicinas: tunc fiat cum instrumento quod nominatur Clepshydra, et haec est forma eius.	 "When the instrument pierces a vein and there is bleeding or clotting of its contents, then gather together water and medicine to treat it with that which is called clepsydra (a device used for measuring out drops), so this is its form.
Est enim surda, id est, clausa.	 "It is silent
Et in eo sunt tria foramina, duo ex parte una, et unum ex parte altera, sicut uides.	 "There are three holes (the artery and two veins), one on each side of the vein.
Et locus concauus, in quo est illud quod impellit, sit secundum quantitatem quod opilet ipsum sine additione, donec quando trahitur cum eo aliquid, ex humiditatibus attrahatur: et quando impellitur, cum eo expellatur ad longinquum: secundum quod facit clepshydra, qua proiicitur naphta, id est, ignis graecus in praeliis martis.	 "The place where the thing pulls is measured according to the amount it exerts without addition (the quantity of drops), until something is drawn with it from dampness; and when it pushes out, with it pushed back to long ago: as clepsydra measures out the flow, that is, Greek fire in the face of men at arms.
Cum ergo uis proiicere humiditates in uesicam, intromitte extremitatem clepshydrae in humiditatem, et trahe cum eo quod impellit ad superiora, humiditas enim trahitur in concauitatem clepshydrae.	 "So when you want to apply moisture to the vein, put its extremity into the moisture and draw it with what pulls up to the top: for the moisture is drawn into the cavity of clepsydra.
Deinde intromitte extremitatem eius in uirgam, secundum quod narrauimus in siringa.	 Then insert his extremity between the thumb and the little finger
Deinde impelle humiditatem cum eo quod impellit illa namque humiditas peruenit ad uesicam statim, ita quod sentit eam infirmus.	 After that, he applies moisture with him as what moved her to come quickly and immediately she felt wet.
Forma clisteris subtilis quo clisterizatur uesica.	 With a soft sponge like this the sponge is made wet.
Fiat ex argento, aut auricalco: cuius caput altius sit simile alcama paruo, et sub eo sinus inter quem cadat ligamentum.	 Let it be of silver or gold, whose head is larger than an egg and has a notch under it to hold the nose?
Deinde accipe uesicam arietis, et pone in ea humiditatem, qua uis clisterizare uesicam.	 Then take the sponge to the fingertips, put moisture into it, with which you wet the sponge.
Deinde liga eam inter duos sinus ligatura forti cum filo duplo: et calefac illam humiditatem parumper super ignem.	 After that tie the sponge between two strong stitches using a double thread, and heat the moisture more than oil.
Deinde intromitte extremitatem clisteris in uirgam, postea stringe manum tuam super uesicam cum humiditate strictura decenti, donec sentiat infirmus, quod illa humiditas iam peruenit ad uesicam.	 Then put the extremity of the sponge between your thumb and little finger, then tie a strong thread with moisture on it and when he feels wet, that's already wet.
Si autem non est tibi praesens uesica, tunc accipe frustum pergameni, et fac ex eo circulum, et perfora ipsum ab omni rotunditate sua.	 If you do not have a sponge at hand, then take the remnant of parchment paper and make a circle with it, and perforate it from all of its circumference.
Deinde intromitte filum forte in illis foraminibus, sicut reuoluuntur.	 After that tie the strong thread between them like how they go together.
Deinde aggrega circulum, sicut aggregatur alsofratu: postquam tu ponis in eo illud quod uis ex humiditatibus, et oleis, et aquis.	 Then you wrap it around, just as the rope is wrapped by oil and water.
Deinde liga ipsum in instrumento: et fac cum eo sicut fecisti cum uesica ex expressione cum manu tua, donec perueniat humiditas ad uesicam.	 Then tie it to an instrument and do with it like you did with the sponge using your hand, until the moisture is added to the sponge.
¶ De extractione Lapidis.	 From the extraction of parchment
Caput LX.	 Head 60.
Iam diximus in diuisione species Lapidis, et curationem eius cum medicinis: et dixi differentiam inter Lapidem generatum in renibus, et uesica, et signa illius totius: et dixi Lapidem in quo cadit operatio cum manu et sectio: et est Lapis generatus in uesica proprie: et ille qui figitur in uirga: et ego sum narrans illud cum expositione manifesta et abbreuiatione.	 We have said about the use of parchment, and its care with medicines: and I have mentioned a difference between those made by artists for writing or sewing, and others used only as a sponge; and I have spoken of the signs on it in general terms, and I spoke of the parchment where the operation is performed using the hand and cutting. And thus we have said about the generation of the parchment itself: and this was done with an open display and abbreviation.
Dico ergo, quod Lapis generatus in uesica, plurimum accidit pueris.	 "Therefore I say that the stone generated from water has caused most harm to children.
Et ex signis eius est, quod urina egreditur ex uesica similis aquae in subtilitate sua: et apparet in ea harena alba, et fricat infirmus uirgam suam, et laborat cum ea, et multotiens pendet.	 "And from these signs it comes that urine is generated by water similar to how water is in its subtlety and appears as a white foam on the water's surface; when it strikes, it makes the man with whom it had intercourse weak, and hard at work, and often drops.
Deinde erigitur, et egreditur cum eo anus in multis eorum.	 "Then afterwards arises, urine from it, as a result of which many people become ill.
Et est facilis sanatio puerorum, ex eo usquequo consequuntur quatuordecim annos.	 "The healing of children is easy, resulting in some cases even up to 14 years.
Et est difficilis in senibus.	 "And it is difficult for the elderly.
In iuuenibus autem est media, in eo quod est inter illud: et eius cuius Lapis est maior, curatio facilior: et si paruus, est econuerso illius cura.	 "In children itself there is a medium degree; it is that which is between the two extremes and whose lapis (stone) is greater in size - its care is easier; if small, then his care is cheaper.
Cum ergo peruenimus ad curationem, oportet in primis, ut mundificemus infirmum cum clisteri, quod extrahat totum stercus quod est in intestinis suis: ipsum enim quandoque prohibet inuentionem Lapidis apud inquisitionem.	 "Since therefore we come to the care of children, it is first necessary, so that we can cleanse them with the help of a cloth; for this reason he sometimes prohibits the stone from being inserted into their bowels during examination.
Deinde accipiatur infirmus cum pedibus suis, et concutiatur, et moueatur ad inferiora: ut descendat Lapis ad profundum uesicae, aut saliat de loco alto aliquotiens.	 "Then the patient is taken with his own feet and moves towards the lower end; so that the stone descends into the water's depths or comes up in some cases from a high place.
Deinde fac eum sedere inter manus tuas praeparatum, et manus eius sint sub coxis ipsius, ut fiat uesica tota decliuis ad inferiora.	 "Then they make him sit between your hands and set his feet beneath the crossbar of their bench; so that all the water may be directed downward towards the lower end.
Deinde perquire eum, et tange eum extrinsecus.	 "Then question him from outside.
Si ergo sentis Lapidem in spacio, tunc propera statim cum sectione super ipsum.	 "If therefore you hear the stone as a space, then immediately apply the cutting instrument to it above and cut off the stone.
Quod si non cadat sub tactu tuo omnino, tunc oportet ut abstergas digitum indicem cum oleo manus sinistrae, si infirmus est puer: aut digitum medium si est iuuenis completus: et intromittas ipsum in anum suum, et perquire de Lapide, donec stat sub digito tuo: et conuerte eum paulatim ad collum uesicae.	 "If it does not fall under your touch at all times, then you should remove the finger indicating a thumb from the left hand if the patient is a child; or use the middle finger if he is an adult and insert him into his anus, and question about the stone until it lies below your finger.
Deinde preme super ipsum cum digito tuo, et impelle ipsum ad exteriora aduersus locus, cuius sectionem uis: et praecipe ministro, ut premat uesicam manu sua, et praecipe alii ministro, ut extendat testiculos manu sua dextra ad superiora: et alia manu sua, ut remoueat cutem, quae est sub testiculis in parte a loco in quo est sectio.	 "Then press with your finger and pull it outward to the external part of its section, wherewith you will open an incision; and then take hold of the minister with one hand, that you may apply your knife with another, and strike downward on the testicle with your left hand, which lies beneath in the part from whence it is cut.
Deinde intromitte Spatumile incidens, cuius forma haec est.	 "Then introduce a blunt instrument into its section, whose shape this is.
Et finde in eo quod est inter anum et testiculos, et non in medio, ad latus natis sinistrae: et sit sectio super ipsum lapidem, et digitus tuus sit in ano: et fiat sectio transuersa, ut sit sectio exterius ampla, et interius stricta, secundum quantitatem quod sit possibile egressio Lapidis ex ea non maior.	 "And find within it what lies between the testicle and anus, but not in its middle; make an incision on the left side from anus to testicle; then strike downward upon it with a stone; your finger should be inserted into its opening; let there be two incisions made one above and one below, according to the quantity of stones that can be extracted downwards without injury.
Fortasse enim comprimit digitus, qui est in ano Lapidem apud sectionem, et egreditur absque difficultate.	 "If you press too hard with your finger into the opening of the stone near its section and it slips out easily without difficulty.
Et scias, quod ex Lapide est cui sunt anguli et margines, quare fit difficilis exitus eius propter illud.	 "You know that from a stone there are angles and margins, for the exit of him is difficult because of those things.
Et ex eo est lenis, similis glandulae, et rotundus: et fit facilis egressus eius.	 "And from it there comes easily, similar to a glans penis, and round; and an easy exit for them.
Ei ergo cui sunt anguli, et margines, adde in fissura.	 "Therefore, add the incision with those angles and margins.
Quod si non egreditur ita, tunc oportet ut ingenies super ipsum: aut stringas super eum cum gesti decenter, cuius extremitas sit sicut Luna, quae stringat super Lapidem, et non euadat ab ea: aut ut intromittas sub eo instrumentum subtile, curuatae extremitatis.	 "If it doesn't slip out that way, then you should press upon its head; or tie it with your hands in a downward motion towards him, the extremity being like to the moon, which holds up to the stone and does not withdraw from it; or introduce some delicate instrument beneath it.
Si autem non potes super cum, tunc amplifica foramen parumper.	 "If you cannot press upon its head, then make a wider opening in front of it.
Quod si uincit te aliquid ex sanguine, abscinde ipsum cum zegi.	 "If something comes from the blood, let go of him with your mouth.
Si uero lapis est plus quam unus, tunc impelle in primis magnum ad os uesicae.	 "If a stone is more than one, then you must first press it into the female's vagina as much as possible.
Deinde incide super ipsum.	 "Then strike upon him above.
Postea impelle paruum post illud: et similiter fac si sunt plures duobus.	 "Then press the others in turn, just as if there were two of them.
Quod si magnus est ualde, tunc ignorantia est ut seces super ipsum sectione magna.	 "If one's knowledge is great, ignorance ensues when he separates a large part from it.
Quoniam accidit infirmo una duarum rerum, aut ut moriatur, aut accidit ei distillatio urinae assidua: proptera, quia non consolidatur locus omnino.	 "When one has fallen ill with two causes or is destined to die of both, the stream of urine will be impeded by a strong flow of urine.
Verum administra expulsionem eius, donec egrediatur: aut ingenia in fractura eius cum forficibus, donec extrahas eum frustatim.	 "Indeed, when one is expelled from office or has fallen apart along with its parts, he will be removed outside of his place.
Cum ergo compleueris operationem tuam, tunc imple uulnus thure, et aloe, et sanguine draconis: et stringe ipsum, et pone super ipsum pannum infusum oleo et uino, aut oleo rosato, et aqua frigida: ut sedetur apostema calidum.	 "Once you have completed your operation, the wound will be healed with honey and aloe; also with dragon's blood; tie him down and lay a warm blanket over him, pour olive oil or wine upon him as it pleases you; also cold water to cool his burning flesh.
Deinde resupina infirmum super collum suum, et non soluas ligamentum, usque ad diem tertium.	 "Then the patient lies on top of his chest and is not supported by a single ligature until after three days have passed.
Cum ergo solueris ipsum, embroca locum cum aqua, et oleo multo.	 "Once he has been bound up, cover him with water and olive oil.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento dyafinicon, et unguento basilicon, donec sanetur.	 "Then care for him with the unguent of Daphne and Basil until he is healed.
Si autem accidit in uulnere apostema calidum additum, et corrosi, et illi similia: sicut si congeletur sanguis in uesica, et prohibeatur ex eo urina: et cognoscitur illud ex egressione sanguinis cum urina.	 "If he is burned by the hot ashes of a victim and becomes corroded; or if his flesh freezes from being exposed to cold water and urine cannot escape out of him until he knows it through the egress of blood with urine.
Intromitte ergo digitum tuum in uulnus, et extrahe illum sanguinem.	 "Therefore put your finger into the wound and remove his blood.
Nam si remanet, prouocat ad corruptionem uesicae, et putrefactionem eius.	 "If this remains, he will become corrupted with urine and decay.
Deinde ablue uulnus cum aceto, et aqua, et sale: et oppone omni speciei cum eo quod conuenit ex curatione, usquequo sanetur.	 "Then wash the wound with vinegar, water, and salt; bind him to everything that was used in his care until he is healed.
Et oportet in horis curationis totius, ut liges duas coxas, et aggreges, caussa medicinarum quae ponuntur super locum.	 "It should be done throughout the course of treatment as long as two attendants are needed and all the equipment placed upon it.
Quod si lapis est paruus, et sit in meatu uirgae, et figitur in eo, et prohibetur urinae exitus: tunc cura ipsum cum eo quod narro antequam peruenias ad sectionem.	 "If a stone is flat and lies on the ground near water; if it is moved by that, urine cannot escape from it; then care must be taken of him with what he knows before dividing.
Multotiens enim a sectione excusaris per hanc curationem, iam enim probaui illud.	 Many thanks for excusing me from this examination, I have already tried that.
Et est, ut accipias Perforatorium ex ferro alferico, cuius haec est forma, triangulatae extremitatis, acutum, fixum in ligno.	 It is as follows: the instrument of perforation with a sharp point, whose shape is triangular at the ends and fixed to wood
Deinde accipe filum, et liga cum eo uirgam sub lapide ut non redeat ad uesicam.	 Then take a rope and tie it around a stone so that it does not slip off easily.
Deinde intromitte ferrum perforans in uirgam cum facilitate, donec perueniat Perforatorium ad ipsum lapidem: et reuolue Perforatorium manu tua in ipso lapide paulatim: et coneris perforationem eius, donec facias ipsum penetrare a parte altera.	 Then introduce the perforator with ease into your hand so that it penetrates to the stone quickly, and return the perforator by using only one's own hand in the stone gently, until you make this perforator penetrate both ends of another part: then do you accomplish this perforation.
Urina namque absoluitur statim.	 Urine will have been excreted immediately.
Deinde preme manum tuam super illud quod remansit ex lapide ab exteriori parte uirgae.	 Then take your hand over the remaining part of the rope that slipped off from outside
Ipse enim frangitur, et egreditur cum urina, et sanatur infirmus.	 This one is broken and returns with urine, and heals any illness.
Si autem non praeparatur tibi haec curatio, propter aliquid quod prohibet ab illo: tunc liga filum sub lapide, et filum aliud supra lapidem.	 If this examination is not prepared for you due to something that prohibits it from doing so, then tie the rope under the stone and another above the stone.
Deinde seca super lapidem in ipsa uirga inter duas ligaturas.	 Then dry over the stone between two ties.
Deinde extrahe ipsum.	 Then remove it.
Postea solue ligamentum, et mundifica sanguinem congelatum, qui fit in uulnere.	 After this, make the frozen blood thaw and free from the wound.
Et non est necessarium ligamentum fili sub lapide, nisi ut non redeat ad uesicam: et ligamentum aliud desuper, nisi ut quando soluitur filum post egressionem lapidis, redeat cutis ad locum suum, et cooperiat uulnus: et propter illud necesse est tibi illud quando ligas filum superius, ut eleues cutem ad superiora, ut redeat apud complementum tuum, et cooperiat uulnus, sicut diximus.	 It is not necessary to tie the rope under the stone unless it does not slip off easily: and another above, unless when you have tied up the rope after escaping from stones, it slips back into its own place, and cooperates with the wound; and for this reason, if you tie the upper part of the rope, so that the skin is returned to its superior position, and cooperates with the wound just as we said.
¶ De extractione Lapidis mulierum.	 From the extraction of women's buttocks.
Caput LXI.	 The end of book 11
Parum generatur Lapis in mulieribus.	 Nothing is generated from a woman by a stone.
Si autem accidat alicui earum lapis, tunc difficilis est curatio, et prohibetur propter modos multos.	 If you meet one of these stones then it is difficult treatment and forbidden because of many ways.
Vnus eorum est: quod mulier fortasse est uirgo.	 "The strength of a woman is greater than that of a man.
Et secundus est, quia tu non inuenis mulierem quae detegat seipsam medico, quando est casta, aut ex habentibus maritos.	 Secondly, because a woman who has taken upon herself to be treated as a physician when she is pure and/or married to a medical practitioner.
Tertius est, quia tu non inuenis mulierem bene scientem hanc artem, praecipue operationem cum manu.	 Thirdly, because you do not treat a wise woman well in this art (surgery), especially when she is performing the task with her own hands.
Et quartus est longinquitas a loco lapidis: quare indiget sectione profunda, et in illo est timor.	 And fourthly, there are stones of the deep pool that require sections because it is dangerous; and this is the fear.
Quod si necessitas prouocat ad illud, tunc oportet ut accipias mulierem medicam, bene scientem: et parum inuenitur.	 If a need arises to do so, then you should take on that woman who is wise and skilled as a physician; only she will be of use.
Si uero priuaris ea, tunc quaere medicum castum, subtilem, et praesenta mulierem obstetricem bene doctam in re mulierum, aut mulierem quae in hac arte innuit partem artis: fac ergo eam praesentem, et praecipue ei, ut faciat totum quod praecipis ei ex inquisitione super lapidem.
