Deinde accipe ex eo quod tibi necesse est: et dissolue ipsum cum aqua et melle, et clisteriza cum eo Sinum: et stringe orificium eius, et dimitte medicinam in eo ad quantitatem duarum horarum.	 Finally, take from him what is necessary for you; and dissolve it with water and honey, shave him with a razor to treat it; And bind up the opening of his wound, and release the medicine given to you according to the two hours.
Deinde extrahe ipsum cum expressione: fac illud diebus tot, donec mundificetur Sinus, et remoueatur foetor.	 Finally take him out with an expression; do this for days until the odor of death is removed and it is gone.
Et quandoque clisterizatur cum aqua cineris, quando non est tibi praesens hoc medicamen: et est, ut accipias cinerem lignorum uitis, aut cinerem ex lignis ilicis: et proiicias super eam aquam.	 And when you shave him with water and ashes, if the medicine is not present to you; and it is necessary for you to take firewood or charcoal, and pour over them water.
Deinde cola eam, et clisteriza cum ea, donec confidas quod Sinus iam ablutus est.	 Finally cleanse him with her, shave him with the ashes until he believes that the nose is clean.
Quod si infirmo non est tolerantia super medicamen aegyptium, neque aquam cineris, tunc clisteriza ipsum cum aqua et melle, cui iam permixtum est aliquid ex ziniar contrito.	 If tolerance is not present over the medicine of ashes, nor water and honey; then shave him with water and honey as before, mixed with something from resin.
Aut clisteriza ipsum cum melle et uino permixtis, quoniam de proprietate mellis est, ut mundificet, et abluat: et uinum facit adhaerere Sinum, praecipue quando in uino est superfluitas stipticitatis et siccitatis.	 Or shave him with honey and wine mixed; because of the property of the bees it will cleanse, and remove impurities from his nose; And give him wine to come off as he pleases when there is excess of stiffness and dryness in the wine.
Cum facis illud aliquotiens, et confidis quod Sinus corruptio iam remota est: tunc clisteriza ipsum cum eo quod facit nasci carnem in eo.	 When you do this repeatedly until he believes that the injury to his nose is far removed; then shave him with what makes flesh grow on it.
Et est, ut accipias ex emplastro dyafinicon: et dissoluas ipsum cum oleo rosato, et uino stiptico: aut clisteriza ipsum cum quibusdam medicinis, et unguentis aliis, quorum proprietates scripsi in tractatu unguentorum.	 "It is necessary to soak the abscess with a solution of vinegar and rose oil, and apply wine as well; or you may soak it with some medicinal ointments, depending on which one suits best.
Quod si orificium Sinus est strictum, in quo non capit cannula clisteris: tunc amplifica ipsum cum ferro parumper: aut pone in ipso licinium inuolutum in unguento aegyptio, aut in unguento basilicon, donec amplificetur.	 If the sinus is narrowed so that no cannula can be inserted through it, then you must widen the cavity by using iron rods; or you may apply a paste of Egyptian ointment and balsam as well, until it is widened.
Et similiter si est orificium etiam amplum, tunc aggrega labia eius cum sutura: et dimitte ex eo quantitatem in quam ingrediatur clistere sine additione.	 And similarly if the cavity has already been enlarged, you must close it again with sutures; and remove as much of whatever is inserted through it without any additional materials.
Et similiter si orificium eius ex quo currit pus, est eleuatum ad superiora: tunc seca ipsum in depressiori loco qui est in ipso, ut currat ex eo pus usque inferius: quoniam pus quando coartatur in profunditate Sinus, prohibet carnem generari in eo.	 And similarly if the cavity where the discharge comes from is very narrow, it has been dried out to the top; then you must apply a remedy of lower pressure in that location inside the sinus itself so that the discharge flows downwards, because when pus coagulates at the bottom of the sinus, it prevents meat being produced there.
Quod si non est tibi possibile secare Sinum circiter inferius eius secundum quod uis: tunc conare, ut praepares membrum praeparatione qua currat ex eo pus cum facilitate secundum quod praeparatur tibi.	 If it is not possible to dry out the sinus from below as described above; then you must stop applying remedies so that a membrane can be prepared and the discharge flows through with help, after having been prepared for you in advance.
Conare, ut non retineatur in eo aliquid ex pus omnino: et accipe medicinas consolidatiuas quae ponuntur super signum, conuenientes ad illud quod uis.	 When applying remedies, make sure nothing other than discharge is retained inside; and take the solidified medicines which are placed above the sign, along with what you need.
Et extende eas super pannum lini.	 And stretch them over the linen.
Et sit pannus tantae quantitatis, qua fiat communicatio totius Sinus.	 And make sure the linen is of sufficient quantity to allow for complete communication through the sinus.
Deinde incide cum forficibus in directo orificii Sinus foramen, amplius orificio Sinus parumper.	 Then strike with a rod at the direct opening of the sinus; widen that opening of the sinus further.
Deinde extende ex unguentis lenibus super pannum alium, secundum quantitatem foraminis: et pone eum super ipsum positione longinqua ab orificio Sinus, ut alleuietur exitus pus ex eo: et non auferas pannum magnum, nisi post dies aliquos uice una.	 Then stretch over the linen with another rod according to the size of the opening; and place it upon him in a long position above the sinus opening so that his discharge may flow out through the discharge from there; but you will not use a large linen unless after several days one is used.
Ille autem qui est super orificium Sinus, est ille quem remoues in omni hora, ut egrediatur quod aggregatur in eo ex pus: et ut scias, an illud quod currit ex eo uirus, est multum, aut parum: aut digestum, aut indigestum.	 That one who is above the opening of the sinus, that one whom you remove at all hours so that it may return to where it has been collected from pus; and so you know, if this thing which flows out through it is much or little: whether digested or not.
Et cum hoc iterum considera locum Sinus ipsius, an in ipso sentiat dominus eius dolorem, aut non sit in eo dolor, et an sit in eo apostema, aut non sit in eo apostema.	 "And having considered this spot further, the master of that place felt his pain, or if there was no pain in it he would not be able to endure it and therefore become insensible.
Cum ergo protenditur medicatio tua taliter, et uides materiam quae egreditur super orificium Sinus, tunc scias, quod Sinus iam adhaeret, aut approximat adhaerentiae: tunc ergo solue ipsum in mane, aut in tertio die: et quando soluis uulnus, tunc permuta pannum alium, et renoua unguentum.	 "And if your treatment is done with such care and the mother of what has been poured over that opening becomes clear, then you know that this place will stay on until it falls off or parts away: so therefore put a strap around him one day or another, or when he has finished his urination, change the cloth for another and wash the wounds.
Si autem egreditur ex Sinu post spacium longum uirus subtile, tunc non desperes de adhaerentia eius, nam sanatio eius appropinquat, quoniam ex hominibus sunt qui tardant generationem carnis in uulneribus suis, et ex eis sunt qui agunt econtrario illius.	 "If the discharge from your place is very long and subtle, then you do not need to worry about it falling off because his treatment will approach him; for there are men who make the generation of flesh in their veins slow-moving, and those who drive against them.
Si autem egreditur ex Sinu post dies multos pus indigestum, tunc scias quod sinus non adhaeret.	 "If discharge from your place is many days long and remains undigested, then you know that the opening will not stay on.
Si ergo tardatur adhaerentia Sinus, et prolongatur res eius: tunc adde in exiccatione medicinarum, uerum faciant medici, ut sint medicinae in substantia sua humidae, et in uirtute sua siccae: sicut unguentum dyafinicon, quando additur in eo superfluitas additionis ex zegi.	 "So if the time for discharge is long and the rest of him remains so as well, then you should give them medicine to excrete their urine and let doctors do it with a wet towel, using water that has been boiled: just like when an unguent is added while there are excessive additions from urine.
Et ex magis ultimo quo curatur, est, ut accipias unguentum dyafinicon, et soluatur cum oleo rosato, et roretur super ipsum uinum antiquum aequale in substantia sua.	 "And at the end of your treatment when you put on the unguent dyafinicon and it is rinsed with boiled oil: and afterwards there should be poured over him an equal amount of old wine from his own substance.
Deinde confice ipsum cum eo, et utere ipso.	 "Then wrap him up tightly after all that, and use him immediately.
Et iam facit simile huic actioni, quando non est tibi praesens unguentum dyafinicon, mel, quando decoquis ipsum, donec ingrossetur, et uteris eo.	 "And this is similar to the treatment when there was no unguent dyafinicon for you at that moment: after he has been washed until it becomes full and used.
Aut accipe myrrham, et aloen, et olibanum: tere totum, et pulueriza illud super mel dum est super ignem.	 "Or take myrrh and aloes too, and olive oil; put on everything and wash it while you are over fire.
Deinde line super ipsum pannum, et stringe ipsum super Sinum: et line cum melle quod decoquisti, donec ingrossatum est: et pulueriza super ipsum species, et pone super ipsum pannum, et stringe eum.	 "Then tie a cloth around him and put it over the place; and tie with that cloth what you washed; until it becomes full: and wash it with water, and then put on the cloth again.
Et quandoque administratur in illo aristolochia longa, et radices lilii coelestis, et est lilium: et farina herbi, et centaurea.	 When this long Aristolochia is administered, its heavenly lily roots and the flower itself are obtained; and the herb's flour, the Centaur's tail.
Utere eis simplicibus, aut aggregatis, tere ea, et cribella ipsa: et pulueriza super mel quod narraui, et utere eo.	 For simple use (take) them separately or mixed together; and make a mash from the roots themselves; and grind it into meal that you may eat from it.
Quod si prolongatur res Sinus, et non sanatur hac curatione: tunc scias, quod in profundo eius est corruptio: aut iam facit impressionem in ossibus, aut in reliquis membris duris, aut ligamentis: tunc cura ipsum curatione Fistularum, secundum quod praemissum est.	 If the sinus (of a patient) is prolonged and does not heal with this treatment; then you know that corruption has already taken place within it; or may have made an impression in the bones, muscles, ligaments, etc.; at that point, care for him as if he were suffering from fistulas.
¶ De cura Panaritii et unguis attritae, et incisione digiti additi, et sectione.	 The cure of ulcers and fingers; the incision of the digits added to it, and the sectioning (of flesh).
Caput XCI.	 Chapter 100
Panaritium est apostema quod nascitur sub ungue pollicis manus, aut pedis: et fortasse nascitur in reliquis digitis.	 An ulcer is an opening that occurs under the thumb or toe of a hand or foot; and often arises on other fingers as well.
Cum ergo prolongatur res eius, et negligitur curato eius, et apostematur apostemate calido: aut corrumpitur, et emittit pus, donec corrodit radicem unguis: et fortasse corrumpit eam totam, et fortasse peruenit corruptio ad os, donec est ei odor foetidus: et fit extremitas digiti lata, et fit color eius fuscus.	 When the matter is prolonged and not properly cared for by the ulcer; or the ulcer turns into a boil that emits pus until it has corroded its root; often this turns completely black, causing corruption to occur in his mouth as well. And if the extremity of the finger becomes necrotic, i.e., dead; then he loses control over him and he is unable to use him any longer.
Quando ergo tu curas ipsum, cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert curatio tua: tunc oportet ut incidas cum ferro totam superfluitatem quae remansit ex ungue.	 When you cure him as we advised earlier, and do not fail to give your full attention; then it is necessary that you strike off with the iron any remaining excess from his finger.
Deinde cauteriza uulnus post illud.	 After this, cauterize the ulcer
Cauterium enim iuuatiuum est ualde.	 The cautery is an instrument of healing.
Si uero os est sanum, et est unguis etiam sana, et additiones uacuae unguis iam comprimunt carnem ad interiora, et incipiunt pungere ipsam, et laedunt eam: tunc oportet ut ponas Radium subtilem sub angulo unguis quae pungit carnem, et impelle eam sursum: et incide eam carnem cum facilitate, et pone super illud quod remanet de carne ex medicinis comburentibus, corrosiuis, donec remoueatur totum eius.	 If his mouth is healed and also his finger; the excess water from his finger will be compressed into flesh on the inside, he will begin to feel pain in him again; then you must apply a small amount of radium beneath an angle that has been puncturing flesh and drive him up towards it: and strike off at once all that remains after being burned by medical compounds or corrosive substances.
Deinde cura illud cum unguentis, donec sanetur.	 "In order that [the healing process] may be done with ointment.
Si autem corruptio iam imprimit in os, tunc oportet ut incidas illud os, et extrahas ipsum: non enim sanatur unquam dum permanet in eo os corruptum.	 "If a corruption has already set in, then you should strike out that mouth and remove it; otherwise [the corrupted material] will never be healed while still within the affected part.
Quod si uides corrosionem et corruptionem incedere in digitum, tunc incide eum in uno nodorum, secundum quod praemissa est eius rememoratio.	 "If you see a corrosion or corruption affecting the finger, then remove it from one of the fingers that remembers its memory; [i.e., if the affected finger is remembered by another finger.]
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	 "Afterwards heal him.
Si autem accidat ungui attritio, aut percussio: et contingit in ea dolor uehemens, tunc oportet ut phlebotomes infirmum in primis.	 "If the finger is injured or broken, then let it be first attended to by a phlebotomist [one who performs bloodletting].
Deinde seca unguem cum Spatumili acuto sectione transuersa de sursum ad uisum.	 "Afterwards dry the finger with an acute cut made from above downwards.
Et custodi, ne sectio perueniat ad carnem quae est sub ungue, nam tu facies accidere per illud super infirmum dolorem uehementem, et erit caussa ad natiuitatem carnis additae in loco.	 "And let the cut be kept from reaching any part that is under the finger; otherwise it will cause great pain to the limb as a result.
Deinde cura locum cum eo quod sedat dolores.	 "Afterwards heal the place where he sits [i.e., where the healing process has been performed].
Digitus uero additus qui nascitur in quibusdam manibus hominum, fortasse est carnosus totus: et fortasse sunt in quibusdam eorum ossa, et fortasse est in eo unguis: et quidam eorum nascitur in radice iuncturae, aut est natiuitas eius in quibusdam nodis digiti.	 "The fingers are the most useful of all members among men; [and] some have bones and others only a finger; and there is one who has his life bound to certain digits.
Ille ergo qui nascitur in quibusdam nodis digiti, non mouetur: et ille qui nascitur apud iuncturam digiti, fortasse mouetur.	 "He [i.e., the person] who is born into some of the digits, will not die; and he who is born at a finger-binding place will be saved.
Eius ergo qui ex eis est carnosus, sectio eius facilis est.	 "Those whose bodies are so [i.e., the bodies to which this passage refers] have cuts easy to make.
Quod est, ut incidas ipsum apud radicem suam cum Spatumili lato.	 "This is what you should do when making a cut on his own finger with an acute blade.
Eius autem cuius natiuitas est in radice iuncturae curatio, est difficilis.	 "The cure of those who have their lives bound to certain digits [i.e., the person] will be difficult.
Abstine ergo ab incisione eius.	 "Therefore let there be a restraint from cutting him.
In illo uero qui nascitur in digito apud ultimum nodorum, tunc oportet ut incidas in primis carnem eius incisione rotunda usque ad os.	 "If the person is born into one of the last digits, then you should strike out his flesh with a blunt blade from below upwards to the mouth.
Deinde serra os cum una illarum Serrarum conuenientium ad illud.	 "In order to cut these tools with one's own sword.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	 "Afterwards apply the remedy.
Consolidatio autem quae accidit digitis adinuicem, multotiens accidit aut ex natiuitate hominis, id est, nascitur cum eo, aut a consolidatione uulneris, aut combustione ignis, et similibus.	 "The consolidated injury is often difficult to heal, especially if it occurred due to a fall of the human body or by heat from fire.
Oportet ergo ut seces illam consolidationem, donec redeant digiti secundum formam suam naturalem.	 "Therefore, in order that the consolidated injury may be separated once again according to its own original shape.
Deinde pone inter eos licinia, aut pannos infusos in oleo rosato: ut non consolidentur uelociter, et separa inter eos: aut pone inter eos laminam plumbi subtilem, donec consolidetur locus secundum quod oportet.	 "After this has been done with the appropriate oil or bandages soaked in olive oil to prevent them from sticking together and separate them; either use a thin strip of lead to bind them back together once again according to what ought to be.
Et similiter si accidat consolidatio quibusdam digitis cum palma, tunc seca illam consolidationem, secundum quod praeparatur et conuenit figurae membri.	 "And similarly if the consolidated injury occurred due to a blow with a palm, then dry it off and restore its shape according to what was prepared.
¶ De incisione Vitium.	 "Regarding the treatment of a broken bone.
Caput XCII.	 "Chapter 22.
Uites sunt Venae inuolutae, grossae, plenae superfluitatibus melancholicis quae accidunt in pluribus membris corporis: et plurimum euentus earum est in cruribus, praecipue in cruribus iter agentium et laborantium, et portantium.	 "The veins that are torn and injured with too much melancholy humor and the result is bleeding from many parts of the body; especially on the arms, face, hands, and feet.
Oportet ergo ut administres excussionem corporis ex cholera nigra aliquotiens excussione forti.	 "Therefore it is necessary to administer a strong emetic for treating excessive vomiting from black bile many times over.
Deinde phlebotoma patientis eas basilicam.	 "Afterwards, the procedure of taking blood from the patient in order to draw off black bile is done on the right arm just below the elbow.
Curatio uero earum cum ferro, est secundum duos modos.	 "The cure for them with iron, it can be done according to two ways.
Vnus eorum est, ut secentur, et extrahatur sanguis niger.	 "One way is for them to bleed by using a lancet and remove the black blood.
Et modus alter est, ut eleuetur Vena, et extrahatur tota.	 "Another way is for you to draw off the whole vein and remove it completely.
Sectio uero eius est secundum hunc modum.	 "The procedure of cutting off their head according to this method must be done carefully.
Embroca crus in primis cum aqua calida multum, donec resoluatur sanguis grossus faeculentus.	 "Firstly take a warm bath with hot water until the large amount of blood is resolved.
Deinde stringe crus infirmi a superiori parte coxae eius, usque ad inferiorem partem genu cum uitta.	 "Afterwards tie down his feet to above his hips and from below his knees to the upper part of his leg with wet cloth so that he does not move.
Deinde seca uenam in loco uno, aut duobus, aut tribus sectione ampla.	 In a single vein or two veins or three veins spread out
Deinde eleua, id est, extrahe sanguinem in manu tua ab inferiori parte cruris, usque ad sursum, et a superiori oportet ut phlebotomes infirmum in primis.	 Then you must first extract blood from the hand near the groin using one vein or two veins and then proceed upwards until you reach the top, after which you should apply the tourniquet to the upper arm for the patient who needs it first.
Deinde seca unguem cum usque inferius: donec egrediatur ex sanguine quantitas quam uides sufficere, et quam tolerat uirtus infirmi.	 Then you should withdraw blood until a sufficient amount has been obtained from the hand up to its lowest point and according to the strength of the patient.
Postea liga eam: et praecipe ei, ut abstineat a cibis generantibus choleram nigram: et itera euacuationem et phlebotomiam, quando implentur Venae, et nocet illud infirmo.	 Afterwards bind her tightly so that she does not drink from the night-dealing spirits and vomiting and phlebotomy when necessary until a vein is found, at which point you should stop to avoid harming the patient.
Eleuatio autem eius est secundum hunc modum.	 The extraction of his blood will be according to this manner.
Rade crus infirmi, si in ea sunt pili multi.	 Shave the arm if there are many hairs on it.
Deinde intromitte ipsum in balneum: aut embroca ipsum in crure eius cum aqua calida, donec rubeat, et exuberentur Venae: aut exercitetur exercitio forti, si non est ei praesens balneum, donec calefiat membrum.	 Then insert him into the bath; or you could warm his arm with hot water until he starts to bleed, and then apply pressure on the veins; or if there is no present vein perform a forceful massage that will heat up the member (I assume this means the arm).
Deinde seca cutem in directo uenae sectione per longitudinem: aut in ultimo eius apud genu, aut in inferiori parte eius apud calcaneum.	 Then you should dry him off directly from one vein along its length; or at his elbow or near the calf depending on where there is dryness (I assume this means veins).
Deinde aperi cutem cum uncinis, et excoria uenam ab omni parte, donec appareat sensui: et est apud apparitionem eius, quod uides eam rubeam ad nigredinem decliuem.	 Then gently remove the bandage from all sides until it is visible to the senses; and you should look for where she bled at her elbow or near the calf so that you can lead her towards the night-dealing spirits.
Cum ergo uadit ex cute, uides eam albam quasi sit chorda.	 Therefore after removing from his bandage gently wipe him off as if he was almost clean.
Deinde intromitte sub ea Radium, donec quando eleuatur et egreditur de cute: suspende eam cum uncino caeco, leni.	 Then insert beneath the radiator until when she is extracted and held in by the bandage; bind her tightly with a blindfold gently.
Deinde seca sectionem aliam prope illam sectionem tribus digitis.	 Then dry another nearby three fingers away from that area.
Deinde excoria cutem a superiori parte uenae, donec appareat.	 Then gently remove the bandage from the upper part one at a time until it becomes visible (I assume this means remove each section of bandage one by one).
Deinde eleua eam cum Radiis sicut fecisti, et suspende eam cum uncino alio, sicut fecisti in primis.	 Then extract her with the radiators as you did before and bind her tightly after that just like you did first time.
Deinde seca sectionem aliam, aut sectiones plures, si indiges illo.	 "If you need another incision (cut) elsewhere on his body or multiple incisions if necessary.
Deinde eleua, et incide ipsam ultima sectione apud calcaneum.	 "After that, make the last incision at the heel.
Deinde extrahe eam ad sectionem quae est supra eam.	 "Take it out and perform the incision above it.
Et fac illud, donec extrahas eam ex sectione quae est superior, uel altior sectionibus omnibus, donec quando egreditur tota: tunc incide eam.	 "After that, take it away from the upper incision or any other incision you may need to make, until you have performed all of them completely; then perform the final incision.
Si autem non obedit tibi ad extrahendum, et eleuandum: tunc intromitte acum cum filo forti duplo, et liga eam, et extrahe ipsam: aut intromitte sub ea Radium: et reuolue manum tuam ad omnem partem, donec egrediatur.	 "If it cannot be removed from the upper incision or any other incision, then introduce a double-edged knife and tie it securely with cord; take out this one as well, either you go under it on the radius of your hand: otherwise turn to the opposite part [of his body], until everything is done.
Et caue, ne incidatur.	 "And so, no incision should be made.
Nam si incidatur, fit difficile tibi eleuare eam ualde, et ingreditur super infirmum ex ea nocumentum.	 "If an incision is made, you will find it very difficult to remove the blade from its place and return it safely above the affected limb.
Cum ergo extraxeris eam totam: tunc pone super locum uulnerum lanam submersam in uino et oleo rosato, aut oleo: et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	 "When you have taken out everything completely, then put the wound-dressing over the place where the limb was cut and apply oil or ointment to it; if the latter is better, cure him.
Quod si Vitis est contracta, habens tortuositatem cui sit inuolutio ad partes, et non est sicut diximus secundum rectitudinem: tunc oportet ut findas super eam ad omnem partem tortuositatis eius, et loca inuolutionis ipsius.	 "If the veins are contracted and twisted around so that they cannot be pulled out in one piece according to our description of their path or order: then it is necessary that you find a way to reach them all over his entire limb and remove the places where there were incisions.
Deinde suspende eam cum uncinis, donec eleues eam totam: et caue apud sectionem tuam super eam ne incidas uenam, aut uulneres: nam difficile fiet super te eleuare, uel extrahere eam.	 "After that, tie it securely with cord until you remove the whole of it; and when you have performed your incision above this one, do not make another one, for it will be very difficult to remove from its place or take out.
Conserua ergo prudentiam tuam.	 "Therefore use prudence in everything you do.
Forma Incidentis quo sanatur Vitis.	 "Shape of the incision where he is treated.
Forma Vncini caeci.	 "The shape for cutting open a vein.
Non est ei curuitas sicut reliquis Vncinis, neque est acutae extremitatis, ut non uulneret uenam: et est grossae flectuositatis, lenis: quoniam si esset subtilis, incideret uenam subtilitate sua: imo sit ei superflua grossitudo, sicut diximus.	 "It is not as curved or acute a vein, and it does not go to the end of that part; but rather it has a large bend and length which makes it easy to remove from its place.
De extractione Venae cruris.	 Extraction of veins from the leg
Caput XCIII.	 Extracting veins from the head is a more advanced technique that requires special tools and expertise.
Haec Vena generatur in cruribus in terris calidis, sicut Alizegi, et terra Arabum, et in terris aridis, calidis, paucae teneritatis, id est, in quibus non nascitur herba, neque arbor.	 This vein is generated from the leg and on hot soil, like a lizard, and on arid soil that is warm but barren, without any vegetation or trees.
Et fortasse generatur in locis aliis corporis praeter crura.	 And sometimes veins may also be found elsewhere in the body outside of the legs.
Et generatio quidem eius est a putrefactione quae accidit sub cute, sicut accidunt intra corpora serpentes et uermes ascarides, et uermes generati inter cutem et carnem.	 The generation of this vein is through the decay that occurs beneath the skin, like how snakes and fleas become generated inside the body.
Et signum incaeptionis euentus huius Venae est, quod accidit in crure inflammatio uehemens.	 The sign of its extraction is when inflammation occurs on the leg veins from a severe heat.
Deinde uesicatur locus.	 Then the location for its removal must be determined.
Deinde incipit Vena exire ex loco illius uesicationis, quasi sit radix plantae, aut animal.	 Then the vein will begin to exit from that location of extraction like a root or an animal part.
Cum ergo apparet ex ea extremitas eius, tunc oportet ut inuoluas super ipsam frustum plumbi, cuius pondus sit ex drachma keil, usque ad drachmas II et noda ipsam: et dimitte plumbum suspensum ex crure.	 When this becomes apparent at the end of that part or root, it is appropriate to close off a small hole in order to hold water until you reach the second and third holes from there (i.e., where the lead enters). And if the lead falls out of the vein into the body then you must remove it from the leg by using a drachm scale as much as two and a half drachms, all the way up to the next hole at the bottom of that vein or root.
Quotiens ergo egreditur ex ea aliquid ad exteriora, inuolue illud in plumbo, et noda illud.	 Therefore, if anything comes out of it through this small part into the water below, you must plug that hole shut right away to keep from letting any more lead out or fall out with a seal made of wax and pitch.
Quod si prolongatur multum, tunc incide partem eius, et inuolue residuum.	 If it has become much longer than this part allows for, then you must cut off that part of the vein itself and plug up the rest of it to keep any more lead from coming out with a seal made from wax and pitch or some other substance.
Et non incidas eam radicitus antequam egrediatur tota.	 Do not cut off that root before all of it has been extracted completely, unless you want to be cutting up parts of your own body while trying to remove the lead from within veins and roots in a dangerous situation where there is little time for careful work.
Quoniam si incidis, contrahitur, et ingreditur in carnem: et facit accidere apostema, et putredinem in loco, et ulcus malum.	 If you cut it off, however, and if the lead falls into the body with that action then a wound will occur at that place, decay of flesh will also be present along with that infection (ulcus means ulcer or sore), making for bad news all around.
Quapropter oportet, ut suauiter tractetur, et extrahatur paulatim, donec egrediatur ex ultimo sui, et non remaneat ex ea aliquid in corpore: et ex hac quidem Vena egreditur in quibusdam hominibus quod est in longitudine sua quinque palmorum et decem.	 "He should be carefully drawn out, and extracted quickly, so that he returns to his original state, without leaving any trace of him within the body; and from this vein there is one taken which goes into certain people, namely five palms long and ten.
Et iam peruenit ad me, quia exiuit uiro ex XX palmis.	 And then he was brought to me because his right arm had been cut off at five palms
Si autem inciditur tibi in hora medicationis tuae: tunc intromitte radium in foramine eius, et perfora eam foramine longo, cum corpore, donec euacuetur totum quod est in ea ex materia: et administra putrefactionem loci cum medicinis diebus aliquot.	 If you are to be operated on at a certain time during your medication; then lead him into the cavity of his body with great force and perforate it from head to toe, until you have completely evacuated what is in her because of the matter: And administer putrefaction and decomposition to the location where he was placed for a period of days.
Deinde cura ipsum curatione apostematum.	 Then attend his care with great attention.
Et haec quidem Vena quandoque habet ramos multos, praecipue quando apparet in iunctura pedis, aut in pede ipso: et accidunt ei orificia multa, et egreditur ex omni orificio ramus.	 And this vein sometimes has many windings, especially when it appears near the foot of a man, or at his own foot; and they are made for him many openings, and are taken from all of them by one winding.
Cura ergo ipsam, sicut diximus in diuisione, et cum eo quod praemissum est.	 Therefore take great care of it as we said before about the division, with what has been removed.
¶ De sectione super Vermes generatos sub cute, et dicitur Aegritudo bouina.	 Of a removal beneath many worms in the womb, and is called "the vein of the liver".
Caput XCIIII.	 Head 44
Haec Aegritudo nominatur in quadam terra apud nos Aegritudo bouina: propterea, quia multotiens accidit bouibus, et est uermis paruus unus, qui nascitur inter cutem et carnem.	 This is called "the vein of the liver" among us on earth at Aegritudo bouina; because it has been struck by many worms and is very thin in relation to its birth, born between the womb and flesh.

Si autem uides eum iam peruenisse in capite prope oculum, tunc stringe sub eo supercilium strictura bona.	 If you want it already from head towards the eye, then bind below on him above eyebrow tight.
Deinde seca super ipsum, et extrahe eum.	 Then dry up from above him, and brought him out of that.

¶ De sectione super aegritudinem Nakir.	 From the incision above the Nakir.
Caput XCV.	 Head of XCV.
Haec aegritudo nominatur in terra nostra Nakir: et est dolor qui accidit in quibusdam membris: deinde permutatur de membro ad membrum.	 This Nakir is called in our land, and it is pain that was inflicted on certain members; then goes from the member to another member.
Et ego quidem iam uidi ipsum, secundum quod narro tibi.	 And I myself already heard this one, according to what I tell you.
Vocatus sum ad mulierem infirmam in quibusdam uillis.	 I am summoned by a sick woman in certain villages.
Et detexit brachium suum, et uidi inflationem paruam in uena funis brachii.	 And he gives his arm out, and heard the swelling of the forearm in a rope of an arm.
Et postquam remansi hora una, uidi unam inflationem incedere cum focili, sicut incedit uermis, ascendendo ad humerum eius uelocius quam esse potest: ut sit sicut argentum uiuum, quando currit de loco ad locum.	 After the time of one hour remained, he heard a swelling to fall with fire, as it fell from wounds; going up towards his arm or place where you can be; so that is like gold flowing, when it runs from location to location.
Recessit ergo dolor ex illo loco, et fixus est in humero.	 The pain therefore recedes from that place and is fixed in the arm.
Deinde sedi hora una, et cucurrit in reliquum corpus, donec perueniret in brachium aliud.	 After a short time has passed, it falls off the end of the body onto the forearm, so then it drops into another arm.
Deinde narrauit mihi, quia reuoluebatur in toto corpore suo, secundum quod uidi.	 It was handed to me since he fell completely within his own body as I had heard.
Miratus sum ergo de uelocitate permutationis eius de membro ad membrum.	 I am amazed therefore by the transfer of its place from one limb to another.
Et ego quidem ante illud non uideram hanc aegritudinem oculis meis taliter secundum hunc modum.	 But I, in turn, had not witnessed this manner of gentleness with my eyes before.
Verumtamen uidi multos, qui inueniunt dolorem permutari de membro ad membrum: et non uidi ipsum oculis, sicut uidi eum in muliere.	 However many others had witnessed the transfer of pain from one limb to another, but I did not see it with my eyes like I saw him in a woman.
Et ego non cogito illud esse, nisi quod est propterea, quod mulier fuit ex illis qui sunt ex uillis sicci corporis detectarum uenarum: hinc ergo apparet sensui illa uentositas permutata.	 But I do not consider this to be the case unless it is because a woman was among those who are detected by signs of their sick bodies, so therefore there appears to my mind that feeling transferred from one limb to another.
Et est necesse, ut non appareant secundum hanc rationem in illis qui sunt deliciosi, et corporibus humidis, occultarum uenarum.	 It is necessary for them not to appear according to this reason among those who are delighted and of the bodies of men, hidden from sight.
Cum ergo uis curationem eius, et sentit patiens illud dolorem: tunc si est apparens tibi oculo, sicut diximus, tunc stringe supra ipsum, et sub ipso uelociter: et seca supra ipsum, donec egrediatur illa uentositas coartata: et cauteriza locum.	 Since you are caring for him and he is a patient suffering that pain, then if it appears before your eyes as I described earlier, then hold it above his body and beneath him too until the transferred feeling returns to its normal state again; in this way it can be cured of its affliction and place will be restored.
Si autem non uides ipsum oculis tuis: tunc cura ipsum cum excussione corporis, et cum eo quod expellit uentositates, et carminat eas cum pillulis foetidis, et pillulis de serapino, et similibus.	 If however you do not see him with your eyes: then care for him along with an excision of the body and what expelled feelings, and drive away those with poisons from the breasts of women, and poison pills also, as well as others similar ones.
¶ De extractione Sagittarum.	 On extracting arrows.
Caput XCVI.	 The end of book 66.
Sagittae diuersificantur secundum species suas, et secundum loca in quibus cadunt ex corpore.	 Arrows are divided according to their kinds and the places where they fall from the body.
Earum uero diuersitas est: quoniam ex eis sunt quae habent cuspides magnos, et paruos: et concauae, et surdae.	 Their diversity is because some of them have large points and blunt ones, hooks or broad heads.
Et ex eis sunt quae habent tres angulos.	 These are those things that have three angles.
Et ex eis quibus sunt linguae.	 and from them come languages
Et ex eis quibus sunt astellae.	 And from these comes the stars
Illae uero quae sunt secundum membra in quibus cadunt, est secundum duos modos.	 Those veins that are divided into parts where they fall down have two modes according to them.
Aut enim membra sunt ex membris principalibus concauis, sicut cerebrum, et cor, et epar, et pulmo, et renes, et intestina, et uesica, et eis similia.	 However the parts of the veins are divided into main partitions as in the case of brain and heart etc., similarly the veins of liver, spleen, intestines etc.
Quando ergo cadit in aliquo horum membrorum, et apparent tibi signa mortis, quae ego narro tibi post, tunc oportet ut deuites extractionem illius sagittae ex eis, nam mors consequitur illum in quo est, in pluribus dispositionibus.	 If therefore a certain member of the body falls down and shows you signs of death as I tell you after, then it is necessary for you to cut out the arrows from those veins as cause of his death was in that place because he was in multiple positions.
Et quando non apparent tibi ista signa mala, et sagitta non est absconsa in profunditate membri, tunc extrahe ipsam, et cura uulnus.	 However when the arrows are not visible to you and have already been cut off from deep in a member then take out them immediately so that it is seen as a wound.
Ex signis enim cerebri quando cadit in eo sagitta, et penetrat os, et egreditur siphac quod est super cerebrum, est: quoniam accidunt ex illo soda uehemens, et scotomia, et uertigo, et rubedo in oculis, et inflatio, et rubedo linguae, et spasmus, et permixtio intellectus, et uomitus cholerae.	 The arrow to the brain when it falls into that is an arrow which penetrates the eye and causes sight loss and vertigo and redness of the eyes and inflammation of the tongue and spasm and mixing of the mind and cholera death
Et fortasse egreditur sanguis ex naribus, aut auribus.	 Perhaps blood will be extracted from the nose or ears.
Et fortasse abscinditur sermo, et destruitur uox.	 Perhaps speech is lost and the voice is destroyed.
Et egreditur ex loco uulneris humiditas alba similis pulti.	 Perhaps it causes a white discharge from the nostrils similar to mucus.
Et exit ex eo simile aquositati carnis.	 And an exit with similar water loss of limbs.
Si ergo apparent tibi ista signa, tunc abstine a curatione, et extrahe sagittam si non egreditur.	 If therefore you see those signs then refrain from the treatment and take out the arrow if it is not extracted.
Signa autem sagittae quando cadit in corde, sunt: quod ipsa est prope mammillam sinistram: et sentit cum ea quasi ipsa sit fixa in re dura, non in re uacua.	 The arrows to the heart when they fall into are: that which is close to the left breast and feels as if it were fixed on a hard thing but not on a soft one.
Et fortasse sagittae est motus similis motui pulsus: et currit ex uulnere sanguis niger.	 The arrows may be like movements similar to those of the pulse and run out from the wound black blood.
Et sequitur illud frigus extremitatum, et sudor frigidus, et syncopis.	 It follows with a severe chill in extremities and cold sweat and syncope (seizure).
Scias ergo, quod mors descendit procul dubio.	 Therefore, death comes near doubt
Et signum sagittae quando uulnerat pulmonem, est exitus sanguinis spumosi ex uulnere: et uasa quae sequuntur collum, apostematur, et mutatur color infirmi.	 And when the arrow of Sagittarius pierced the lung, death came from blood spurting out through the wound: and those who follow behind are cut off, and their bodies change color due to injury
Et expirat spiritum magnum, altum: et quaerit attractionem aeris frigidi.	 And death takes away great breath as well, high up: seeking the attraction of cold air.
Quod si cadat sagitta in uelamen, quod est in pectore: tunc est prope costas paruas: et fit anhelitus magnus cum dolore uehementi, cum suspirio: et mouentur omnia membra humerorum.	 When the arrow falls into a man's chest, that is when death comes quickly near at his back, and great desire for breath with pain strikes him as he gasps, and all limbs move in death.
Et si cadat sagitta in stomachum, tunc fortasse egreditur ex uulnere ex cibo aliquid indigestum.	 If the arrow falls into a man's stomach, then quickly it will come from the wound by food to something unchewed.
Et si cadit sagitta in Ventrem, et figitur in eo: egreditur aliquid stercoris ex uulnere, aut zirbum, aut intestinum quod iam disruptum est.	 If an arrow falls into the windpipe and sticks there, then it will come from that wound to something of excrement or vomit which has already been disrupted.
Non est ergo spes in curatione eius, neque in extractione sagittae.	 Therefore no hope for him is there in his care nor the arrow's extraction.
Quod si sagitta cadat in Vesicam, et egrediatur urina: et procedit ex ea aliquid ad exteriora, et fortior sit dolor super infirmum: tunc scias, quia est mortale.	 If an arrow falls into the bladder and comes out urine: it proceeds to something outside of that, and the pain is greater upon the sick person; then you know that death will come soon.
Reliqua autem membra, sicut facies, et collum, et guttur, et spatula, et adiutorium, et spondiles dorsi, et furcula, et coxa, et crus, et eis similia ex membris saluantur secundum plures dispositiones: quando non inuenit sagitta arteriam, aut neruum: et non est sagitta uenenosa.	 After all the limbs of a man have fallen away according to many dispositions as mentioned before when Sagittarius did not pierce an artery or vein: and the arrow is not successful
Et ego narro tibi quod uidi de esse harum sagittarum, ut significes per illud super curationem tuam.	 And I tell you that which I heard of these arrows so as to signify it for your care.
Quod est, quia cuidam uiro cecidit sagitta in lachrymali oculi eius, in radice nasi.	 It was because one eye of him was killed by the arrow at his lacrimal canal and nose root
Extraxi ergo eam ipsi ex parte altera, sub adipe auris eius: et sanatus est, et non accidit ei in oculo eius nocumentum.	 Therefore he took that out of one other side under the ear of him, and was healed, and did not come to his eye any more harm.
Et extraxi sagittam aliam Iudaeo, quae cecidit ei in adipe oculi sui sub palpebra inferiori: et sagitta iam occultata erat, et non consecutus sum ex ea nisi extremitatem paruam eius, cum qua adhaeret in ligno suo: et erat sagitta magna ex sagittis arcuum Turcorum, cum ferro leni, in qua non sunt aures.	 Therefore he took another arrow which had killed him at the eyebrow of his eye under the lower eyelid: and that arrow was hidden, and I did not take it off except for a little part of his limb with which it adhered to his wood, because that arrow held on strongly in its bow, being made of iron, without any ears.
Sanatus est ergo Iudaeus, et non accidit in oculo eius accidens malum.	 The Jewish man is healthy and has not suffered a misfortune at his eye's level
Et extraxi sagittam aliam ex gutture Christiani.	 He extracted another arrow from the gut of a Christian.
Et erat sagitta arabica, et est illa cui sunt aures.	 The arrow was Arabic and is in his ears.
Secui ergo super ipsam inter duas guidegi: et iam submersa erat in gutture eius.	 Therefore I pulled him through the two guides; he was already submerged in his gut.
Subtiliatus sum ergo cum ea, donec extraxi eam: et sanatus est Christianus.	 I became subtle with her and when I extracted her out of there she became healthy again; becoming a Christian too.
Et extraxi sagittam aliam uiro quae ceciderat in uentre eius: et cogitauimus, quia moreretur ex ea.	 He extracted another arrow that had entered his belly and we pondered because of its death; it was about to die from it
Postquam ergo praeterierunt ei triginta dies, et non mutatum est super eum aliquid ex dispositionibus eius, secui super sagittam: et ingeniaui super eam, et extraxi eam: et sanatus est, et non accidit ei accidens malum.	 After thirty days passed over him nothing had changed about his disposition; I pulled the arrow out from where it was and the intelligence of my mind with her and extracted her; he became healthy again and did not suffer a misfortune at his eye's level
Et uidi uirum cui cecidit sagitta in dorso eius, et consolidatum est uulnus super eam.	 I heard of the man who had an arrow in his back; he was cured because it was pulled out.
Postquam ergo fuit post septem annos, exiuit sagitta in radice coxae eius.	 After seven years the arrow left his heel.
Et uidi mulierem cui cecidit in uentre suo sagitta, et consolidatum est uulnus super eam, et remansit sagitta intra ipsam: et non mutata est ex dispositionibus eius aliqua, et mulier non inuenit ei nocumentum in aliqua ex operationibus suis naturalibus.	 I heard of a woman who had an arrow that entered her belly; the wound was healed over her and remained inside her but there was no change to her disposition and she did not suffer from any misfortune caused by her own actions.
Et uidi uirum alium, cui cecidit sagitta in facie sua: et consolidatum est uulnus, et remansit, non inueniens ei multum dolorem: et similia istis multa.	 I heard of another man who had an arrow that entered his face; the wound was healed and remained there, not causing him much pain; these many are similar.
Et extraxi sagittam uiro ex principibus Regis, quae ceciderat ei in medio nasi sui, et iam declinauerat ad partem dextram parumper: et occultata erat sagitta tota.	 He extracted the arrow of a king from his middle nasal bone; it had already descended towards his right side and was concealed altogether.
Vocatus sum ergo ad curationem eius post casum sagittae usque ad tres dies.	 Therefore, I called on his healing after the three days were over.
Inueni ergo uulnus sagittae strictum ualde.	 But he did not die from the wound of the arrow.
Inquisiui ergo eam cum tenta subtili, et non sensi eam: et ipse quidem inueniebat punctionem et dolorem sub aure sua ex parte dextra.	 I spoke to him with subtlety and he did not hear me; but the same man was experiencing pain and torment beneath his ear from the right side
Speraui ergo, quod erat illa punctio ex extremitate sagittae.	 I pierced it (the arrow) at its extreme point
Emplastraui ergo locum cum emplastro in quo erat uirtus attractiua, et digestiua, confidens apud me, quod apostemaretur locus, et appareret mihi signum sagittae, ut secarem super eam: et non accidit in loco accidens significans quod sagitta consecuta sit locum.	 I drew it out (the arrow) from the bandage where its virtue was contained and digested; trusting that the place where it had been removed would be shown to me, so that I could remove it myself: but did not fall at a place indicating where the arrow had fallen.
Assiduaui ergo cum emplastro super eum diebus multis: et non accidit accidens, et consolidatum est uulnus interim: et remansit infirmus de extractione eius spacio dierum, donec sensit sagittam die quodam intra nasum suum.	 I persevered with the bandage on him for many days; and did not fall at a place indicating where it had fallen; but was healed of its removal in the meantime: and remained weak from having been taken out of his space during those days, until he felt an arrow one day inside his nose.
Et narrauit mihi illud.	 And told me that
Posui ergo super illud uulnus medicinam acutam, corrosiuam diebus multis, donec apertum est: et cum tenta tentaui ipsum, et sensi extremitatem sagittae subtilem quae adhaeret in ligno.	 I placed the acute bandage on it for many days; until one day was open up: and when I tried to lift him gently with both hands, I felt a subtle extreme point of his arrow hidden within the wood.
Deinde addidi in apertione uulneris per illam medicinam acutam, donec apparuit nobis uisibiliter extremitas sagittae: et praeteriit mihi cum eo spacium temporis circiter quatuor menses.	 After that I put on the acute bandage in opening of the wound; until one day we saw it clearly with both eyes, and he left me with him for a time period of about four months.
Deinde postquam amplificatum est uulnus, et possible fuit mihi intromittere forcipes in ipsam, et mouere ipsam, et non obediuit ad exitum: tunc non cessaui subtiliare, et ingeniare super eam cum modis ingeniorum, donec coepi super eam die quodam cum forcipibus decenter factis, secundum quod ueniet forma eorum in fine capituli, donec extraxi eam.	 After it had been enlarged and was possible for me to grip her with my fingers; and move her too, but she did not yield to being taken away: then I could no longer gently touch or try to lift her using the manner of children; until one day came when I grasped her forcefully with stronger tools, according to which form they had reached in the end of the chapter, until I took her away.
Deinde restauraui uulnus.	 After that I restored the wound.
Et medici quidem iudicant, quod cartilago nasi non restauratur.	 And doctors say that cartilage of the nose is not restoreable.
Restauraui ergo ipsam, et consolidatum est uulnus, et sanatus est infirmas sanitate integra: nec nocuit ei aliquid omnino.	 I therefore restored her and healed the wound and was healthy in health and whole again; no harm came to him at all.
Et ego narro tibi qualitatem extractionis quarundam sagittarum: ut ponas illud regulam et significationem super illud quod non dixi.	 And I told you the quality of extracting arrows some time ago, so that you put this rule and meaning above it which I did not say.
Quoniam partes huius artis et distinctiones earum non comprehenduntur cum narratione: neque comprehendit illud liber, et artifex prudens comparat cum pauco super multum: et cum eo quod est paesens, super illud quod est absens: et inuenit operationem nouam, et instrumentum nouum apud descensus rerum extranearum huius artis quando accidunt.	 Although parts of this art and its distinctions are not comprehended with narration, nor is it comprehended by that book alone, but the wise craftsman compares them to little more than much; he compares what is present with what is absent, from which new operation arises, and a new instrument comes into play when they occur among things extraneous to this art.
Dico ergo, quod sagittae non egrediuntur ex membris quibus sunt fixae, nisi secundum duos modos.	 Therefore I conclude that the arrows are not removed from the members in which they are fastened, except according to two ways.
Aut per attractionem ex loco ex quo intrauit.	 Or by an attraction from where it entered inside.
Aut contrario partis alterius.	 Or on the contrary parts of another.
Et illa quae egreditur unde intrauit, aut est sagitta procedens in loco carnoso: et attrahitur, et egreditur.	 And that which is removed where it entered, or an arrow proceeding to a place of flesh; and it is pulled towards it, and it is removed.
Quod si non obedit ad exitum ex hora in qua cadit: tunc oportet ut dimittas ipsam aliquot diebus, donec putrefiat caro quae est in circumitu eius: et alleuietur attractio eius, et eius egressio.	 What if it does not lead to the exit at a certain time when it falls; then you must wait until that same arrow has died for several days, lest the flesh around him putrefy and cause his death: And will cease attraction towards him, and his exit from there.
Et similiter si figitur in osse, et non obedit tibi ad exitum, tunc dimitte ipsam etiam aliquot diebus: et itera eam cum attractione et motione omni die, donec egreditur.	 And similarly if the arrow is embedded into bone and does not lead you to the exit; then immediately remove that one as well for several days until this arrow with attraction and movement every day no longer stays there.
Quod si non obedit tibi ad exitum post dies, tunc oportet ut perfores in circumitu sagittae in ipso osse ab omni parte cum terebro subtili, donec amplificentur sagittae.	 What if it does not lead you to the exit after a day; then you must remove from around him arrows of all parts with fine strokes skillfully until they become inflated.
Deinde attrahe eam, et extrahe ipsam.	 Then pull her out and remove her.
Si autem sagitta est fixa in capitis osse, et iam processit in uno uentrium cerebri, et apparent ex infirmo quaedam illorum accidentium quae dixi: tunc abstine ab attractione sagittae, et dimitte eam, donec aequetur esse eius post dies.	 If the arrow is firmly fixed in the skull of bone and has already proceeded into one vein of the brain; then abstain from attracting arrows, and remove her until it becomes equal to be with him after days.
Nam si sagitta peruenit ad sifach, tunc mors non prolongatur ei.	 For if an arrow penetrates to the heart, death is not prolonged for him.
Et si sagitta non est fixa, nisi in corpore ossis tantum, et non penetrat usque ad sifach: et remanet infirmus aliquot diebus, et non accidit ei ex illis accidentibus aliquid: tunc ingenia in attractione sagittae et extractione eius.	 And if the arrow is not fixed except in the bones of the body and does not penetrate all the way to the heart; it remains weakened for several days, and nothing happens by accidents from these; then the intention with attracting arrows and removing him.
Si autem est fixa ualde, et non obedit tibi ad attractionem: tunc administra terebella in circumitu sagittae, sicut narraui tibl: deinde cura locum, donec sanetur.	 "If a fracture is fixed and will not yield to your manipulation, then apply the tongs (tibulae) around it as described above; thereafter treat the area as before until healing occurs.
Si autem Sagitta iam absconsa est in loco corporis, et occultatur et absconditur a sensu: tunc inquire eam cum tenta.	 "If the arrow has already been extracted from its place within the body and is hidden or hidden away by touch; then examine her with your fingers.
Si autem sentis eam, tunc attrahe eam cum quibusdam instrumentis quae conueniunt attractioni eius.	 "If you feel it, then grasp it using certain instruments which are suitable for such an action of his.
Si autem non potes super eam, propter constrictionem uulneris, et propter longitudinem sagittae in profundo: et non est illic os, neque neruus, neque uena: tunc finde super eam, donec amplificetur uulnus, et sit possibile extrahere sagittam.	 "If you cannot reach over it due to the constriction of your limbs and the length of the arrow in depth; there is no mouth or vein nearby so that you can grasp her, but only skin: then find around her until she enlarges her limb which will make it possible to extract the arrow.
Quod si sunt ei aures quibus teneatur, tunc libera carnem fixam in eis ab omni parte, omni ingenio quo potes illud, et ingenia, si non potest super euasionem carnis in fractura aurium, et contorsione earum, donec euadat.	 "If you have ears which are bound up, then release the fixed flesh from all parts and with every ability that you possess it, as intelligence if your limbs cannot reach over her to fracture her ear or twist them; until this occurs.
Et tu quando administras extractionem Sagittae, in quocumque loco est, tunc utere contorsione manus tuae, cum forficibus ad partes omnes, donec facias eam euadere: et subtilia ultima subtilitate, ut non frangatur Sagita, et fiat difficilis tibi attractio eius, et ipsius extractio.	 "And when you administer the extraction of an arrow wherever it is, then use the pressure of your hands with all parts; until this occurs: and finally in subtlety, so that she does not break apart, but there will be great difficulty for you to grasp her as well, and hers extraction.
Quod si non potes super eam ex hora una, tunc dimitte eam diebus aliquot, donec putrefiant quae sunt in circumitu eius.	 "If you cannot reach over her from one side alone at first, then set her aside for several days until those around her are putrefied.
Deinde itera eam: alleuietur enim tuncia Si uero contrarietatem tibi facit fluxus sanguinis, tunc administra quod diximus ex curatione in capitulo suo: et custodi uirtutem tuam ab incisione uenae, aut nerui, aut chordae.	 "Then continue with her again; and let the tunic be loosened if she opposes you by a flow of blood, then administer what we mentioned from our chapter on care for the body: and take care to keep your strength intact from one incision or vein.
Et administra ingenium omni modo quo tibi possibile est euasionis Sagittae: et sit illud cum facilitate, et tranquillitate, uel tarditate, et firmitate, sicut narraui tibi.	 "And administer every ability that is suitable for grasping the arrow in any way; and it will be with ease and tranquility or delay and firmness as described to you.
Et oportet, ut facias cum trahis Sagittam, ut infirmus sit secundum figuram, secundum quam fuit apud casum Sagittae in ipso.	 "And there is the need that when you draw her back so she weakens according to the figure which was at the moment of arrow extraction; as it was before.
Quoniam est magis iuuatiuum.	 "For it is more painful.
Si autem non est tibi possibile illud, tunc administra quod tibi est possibile ex figuris.	 If you are unable to do that yourself, then perform the task as shown in an illustration.
Sagitta autem quae egreditur ex contrario partis alterius, aut iam procedit ex ea aliquid ad exteriora: aut facit gibbositatem extremitas Sagittae per sensum ex superiore parte cutis propinquae, et uides eam eminentem: seca ergo super eam, et sit sectio secundum quantitatem quod capiant in ea forcipes.	 A light that is drawn from the contrary part of one another or has already proceeded by it to something external: or does it cause a stiffness in the extremities of the Archer through a feeling out of the higher part of the skin, and you see its excellence clearly defined: therefore it should be cut off with a line following the quantity that can reach it with hooks.
Deinde attrahe eam: ipsa namque fit facilis ad exitum.	 Then draw her out easily to come to an end.
Si uero retinetur in osse, tunc torque manum tuam secundum rotunditatem, donec imprimat Sagitta in osse, et amplificet sibiipsi: deinde trahe ipsam.	 If the Arrow is held on bone instead, then you should apply your hand according to its roundness until the Arrow is set into the bone and extends itself: after that draw her out.
Et si non: dimitte eam diebus aliquot: deinde itera eam, donec egrediatur.	 And if not: then let her be released in a certain number of days; thereafter you will do the same to her until she is complete.
Quod si lignum Sagittae est in ea, tunc impelle ipsam cum eo.	 If the Archer's wood is within it, then pull her along with it.
Si autem cecidit lignum, et uis administrare impulsionem: tunc intromitte ad eam instrumentum concauum, ut ingrediatur concauitas eius in caudam Sagittae: deinde impelle eam cum ipso.	 However if the Archer's wood has been cut off and you are to administer its impulse - then introduce an appropriate tool so that its fullness may enter into her [i.e., fit] and then pull her along with it.
Si autem Sagita est concaua, tunc impelle eam cum instrumento intrante in ipsam.	 If the Archer is fitted, then pull her out with an appropriate tool inserted into her.
Sagitta enim alleuiatur per illud.	 The Archer is released through that.
Quod si Sagitta est toxicata, tunc oportet, ut concaues carnem totam, in qua est uenenum: si est tibi possibile illud.	 If the Archer's wood has been poisoned then you must cut off all of its flesh that contains venom - if possible do this
Deinde cura eam cum eo quod conuenit ad illud.	 Then care for her with what matches it
Quod si Sagitta est cadens in pectore, aut in uentre, aut in uesica, aut in latere: et est propinqua ex eo quod tangis cum tenta, et possibile est tibi secare super eam: tunc seca, et caue ab incisione uenae, aut nerui, et extrahe eam.	 If the Archer falls into the chest or the belly or the side or the thigh - and she touches by her tentacle what is near to it - then you can cut off above her if possible: after that let a hook take hold of her and draw her out.
Deinde sue uulnus, si uides, et cura illud, donec sanetur.	 And then apply your ointment, if you see fit, until she is healed.
Et haec est forma Forcipum, quibus extrahuntur Sagittae.	 This is the shape of a needle trap, which can be used for drawing arrows out
Sint extremitates similes rostro auis, quae factae sunt sicut ferra: quando capiunt super Sagittam, non dimittunt eam.	 The extremities are like the blade of a knife; when they grasp onto an arrowhead, they do not let go
Et fiunt ex eis species multae, magnae, et paruae, et mediae, secundum quantitatem magnitudinis Sagittae, et paruitatis eius, et amplitudinis uulneris, et constrictionis eius.	 There are various kinds of needle traps with different sizes and shapes based on the length and breadth of the arrowhead; they adjust to the strength and flexibility required for gripping it tightly and releasing it quickly.
Forma Impellentis concaui.	 The shape of a snare which is used to catch or hold something, often in hunting or fishing.
Et forma Impellentis surdi.	 The shape of a hook that can be inserted into an animal's mouth for capturing it, typically used in fishing and sometimes in hunting.
Hoc est surdae extremitatis sicut Radius, ut alleuietur introitus eius in sagittam concauam, et impellatur cum eo.	 These extremities are like a curved arm, so that on inserting them into the arrow, they can be withdrawn and then used to pull it back towards themselves
Huius extremitas impellentis concauae est concaua sicut penna auis: ut alleuietur introitus sagittae in ipsam et impulsio eius.	 The extremity of the snare is curved like a bird's beak, so that on inserting it into an arrow, one can be withdrawn out and then used to pull it back towards themselves.
¶ De phlebotomia Venarum.	 On the subject of phlebotomy for veins.
Caput XCVII.	 Section Seventy-Seven.
Uenae phlebotomandae, quarum cucurrit consuetudo in corpore, sunt triginta.	 The needles used for phlebotomy are thirty in number.
Ex quibus in capite sunt sexdecim: duae Venae pulsatiles, quae sunt post aures, dictae duae Herbae: et duae Arteriae, quae sunt in duobus timporibus apparentes: et duae Venae quae sunt in duobus lachrymalibus duorum oculorum, quae dicuntur Aspicientes: et Vena praeparata in medio frontis: et uena quae est in extremitate nasi.	 These needles are six decads long; two for the veins behind the ears (the auricular veins); and then another two veins from each of the eyes, which are called the aspicientiae or "tears" veins. And one more vein is found on the face between the eyes. There's also a vein at the end of the nose
Et duae Guidegi, quae sunt in collo.	 These needles have two guides for use with a guide-wire: one in the neck and another behind the ears.
Et duae uenae quae sunt in labio superiore oris.	 These needles are of two types, used in the upper lip of the mouth.
Et duae uenae quae sunt in labio inferiore.	 These needles have two types that are used at the lower lip of the mouth.
Et istae sunt uenae quae dicuntur Algecherich.	 These needles are called "Algeric".
Et duae uenae quae sunt sub lingua.	 These needles have two types used below the tongue.
Venae autem quae phlebotomantur in brachiis, sunt quinque uenae in omni brachio.	 The veins used for phlebotomy are five in number throughout both arms.
Vna earum est Cephalica, et est ex latere syluestri: et nominat eam uulgus uenam capitis.	 The brain is called the uppermost part of the skull
Et Fusca.	 and Cerebellum
Et est Media uena, et est composita ex ramo Basilicae, et ramo Cephalicae: et nominat eam uulgus uenam corporis.	 And the cerebellum (also known as the "middle brain") is made up of two parts - one from the base and another from the top part of the skull.
Et Basilica, et est posita in latere domestico: et nominatur etiam Titillicaris.	 And the cerebellum is placed at the back of the house (or base) and also called "titicollis" (meaning "little tail").
Et nominat eam uulgus uenam uentris.	 It is named as "the brain of the skull".
Et Funis brachii, et est posita super focile: et est illa in qua phlebotomatur, et est illa quae apparet supra pollicem appatitione manifesta.	 The brain stem (also known as the "funis" or "funicle") is placed above the eye socket and is that part where blood is drawn from a vein; it is also called "the one below which you see when pressing on your finger".
Et Saluatella: et est uena quae est inter annularem et minimum: et sunt ei duo rami.	 The salutation (or "salute") is placed between the annuli (or rings) and at its lowest point; it has two parts, one above and one below.
Et in crure et in pede sunt tres uenae.	 It is present in the neck and foot each with three parts.
Vna earum est quae est sub pollicis curuatura ex latere syluestri.	 The brain is below the finger, at its side (or base), from the top part of the skull.
Et secunda est Saphena: et locus eius est apud calcaneum ex latere domestico.	 The second one is "sapeha" and its location is at the heel or ankle, coming out from the back side (or base).
Et uena Nesse: et locus eius est apud calcaneum ex latere syluestri.	 The third one is "nensee" and its location is at the ankle (or foot), also coming from the base side.
Et in crure alio sunt tres uenae similes illis.	 And in the neck there are three similar parts to those mentioned above.
¶ De phlebotomia duarum uenarum post Aures.	 About the drawing of blood from two veins after the ears.
Phlebotomiae uero duarum uenarum quae sunt post Aures, iuuamentum est ad catarros antiquos, et hemigraneam, et sahafati, et ulcera capitis mala antiqua.	 About drawing blood from two veins behind the ears; it is customary to perform this task with an old-fashioned tool, a pair of tweezers and a lancet for cutting open the vein at its base or top, but always causing damage to the head's scalp in the process.
Et qualitas phlebotomandi eam est secundum quod narro.	 The quality of drawing blood from this source is according to how narrow it is.
Et est, ut radatur caput infirmi: et fricetur occipitium eius in loco duarum uenarum cum panno aspero fricatione bona.	 It is necessary that the head be held gently and the neck of the vein must be gently squeezed with a good cloth to prevent it from moving around while drawing blood.
Deinde stringat infirmus collum suum cum uitta, donec appareant duae uenae.	 Then the veins will become visible as two pieces when the patient raises his arm and pulls back on the cloth holding them.
Et loca earum sunt post Aures in duobus locis depressis capitis.	 In those ears are placed after the auricles in two depressions of the heads
Quaere ergo eas digito tuo, et ubi sentis pulsum earum sub digito tuo, illic signa cum encaustro.	 Seek therefore these ears with your finger and when you feel the pulse in them place a mark with ink
Deinde accipe phlebotomum cultellarem, et est ille qui dicitur Incidens.	 After that take hold of the phlebotomist's arm, and if he says 'Incidens' let him know.
Deinde intromitte ipsum sub uena in cute, donec perueniat phlebotomus ad os.	 After that lead him down to a bed with arms outspread, so that the phlebotomist may approach you from below.
Deinde eleua manum tuam cum uena et cute ad superiora, et incide uenam cum cute incisione incidente.	 After that take hold of your hand and place it upon his upper arm, and strike this with a stroke downward toward 'Incidens'.
Et sit longitudo incisionis quantitas duorum digitorum iunctorum, aut circiter illud: et fac exire ex sanguine quantum uis.	 The length of the incision must be measured by the number of your fingers joined together, or around it, and remove from this as much blood as you wish.
Deinde stringe eam cum puluillis, et dimitte eam, donec sanetur.	 After that stretch out with a pulley, and then let go, so that they might be released.
Et iam praecessit in principio libri incisio earum, et ipsarum cauterizatio.	 And there follows the opening of this book on ears, and their cautery
¶ De phlebotomia duarum Arteriarum in timporibus.	 Of phlebotomy in both arteries in time.
Duarum uero Arteriarum quae sunt in duobus timporibus phlebotomiae iuuamentum, est ad hemigraneam antiquam: et sodam prauam, et obtalmiam assiduam: et cursum superfluitatum effusarum acutarum ad oculos.	 Of the two arteries that are in two times of phlebotomy and the old one, and the fast one, and the most frequent one, it is to the eyes' sharp flow and excess flow
Et qualitas phlebotomandi eas est secundum quod narro tibi.	 The quality of phlebotomy for them is according to what you have spoken.
Stringat infirmus collum suum multum, donec appareant duae uenae sensui apparitione manifesta: et demonstretur pulsus earum sub digito tuo.	 If a man is greatly sick then he should stretch his neck very much, so that the two veins may be clearly visible to you and there will strike the pulse of them under your finger.
Tunc enim signa cum encaustro.	 Then signs with ink.
Deinde eleua cutem desuper uenam ad superiora cum digito tuo indice, et intromitte phlebotomum incidentem desubtus, et eleua uenam ad superiora.	 After that take hold of the upper arm with your finger and lead the phlebotomist downward toward 'Incidens', then take hold of him at the top.
Et incide eam, sicut fecisti in duabus uenis aliis: et fac currere ex sanguine secundum quantitatem necessitatis tuae.	 And strike with a stroke downward upon her as you did on two other veins, and let blood flow according to the amount of your need.
Deinde solue coartationem infirmi, et pone digitum tuum super uenam hora una.	 After that break open the obstruction for him, place your finger upon her one by one hour by hour.
Postea pone super ipsam cotum et puluillos, et stringe ipsum desuper constrictione forti: et dimitte ipsam, donec sanetur.	 With a knot at its base and a loop at one end, tighten it with an extremely strong cord (or something like that). And then release the knot to make him/it stand on his/its own two feet.
Et iam praecessit rememoratio earum, et ipsarum incisio, et earum extractio in principio libri.	 Now let's remember what was said before and their incision as well as the extraction of the book at the beginning.
¶ De phlebotomia uenae frontis post phlebotomiam Cephalicae.	 After performing venepuncture on one side, proceed to perform cephalic vein puncture
Iuuamentum uero phlebotomiae uenae frontis est post phlebotomiam Cephalicae, ad aegritudines faciei antiquas: et ad hemigraneam, et rubedinem: et ulcera foeda.	 The bandage on the arm after venepuncture is to be applied once the cephalic vein has been punctured and before moving or lifting an arm; it should cover any bruises, scratches, or wounds that may have occurred during the procedure.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, secundum quod narro tibi.	 The quality of venepuncture is to be determined by how narrow you open your vein.
Coartet infirmus collum suum cum uitta, donec appareat uena.	 The arm must be raised up off the bed until it appears one's head.
Deinde accipe instrumentum quod nominatur Fossorium.	 Then take an instrument called a foal or an apice.
Cuius haec est forma.	 Its form is like that of
Pone acumen eminens quod est in capite Fossorii super ipsam uenam, et percute super ipsum cum pectine, aut cum re alia in modo eius: et dimitte sanguinem currere secundum quantitatem quam uis.	 Take the instrument and place it at the top of the foal or apice (a small loop used for venepuncture) on your arm so that its sharp point is directed towards the cephalic vein you just punctured, either striking upwards through it directly with a pectine (a curved blade), or to one side in some other way. And then release it from the blood flowing out as much as possible according to the quantity of blood drawn.
Deinde solue perforationem infirmi, et stringe eam, donec sanetur.	 Then make a small incision near where you inserted the instrument, and tighten it so that your arm is supported in place.
Et quandoque aperitur cum phlebotomo lato.	 And when venepuncture was made to one side.
Verumtamen non oportet, ut sit phlebotomus acutae extremitatis, sicut reliqui phlebotomi, imo sit latae extremitatis.	 However it is not necessary that the venepuncture be at the extreme point of the arm, as with other venepunctures made on both sides, in this case we should aim for a point on the opposite side.
Et phlebotoma eam secundum transuersionem: quoniam os est propinquum: et fortasse in eo frangetur phlebotomus quando est subtilis.	 The venepuncture will be made on that side of the arm which is closest to you, unless it would make the instrument too sharp when it's very soft and flexible, in that case move across a little further.
¶ De phlebotomia Venarum in duobus Lachrymalibus.	 Now let's remember how to perform venepuncture on both lachrymose veins.
Iuuamentum autem duarum Venarum quae sunt in duobus Lachrymalibus duorum oculorum, est ad oculum ex scabie et rubedine: et sebel in oculo, et aegritudinibus faciei.	 The bandage on the arm after venepuncture of both lachrymose veins is to be applied when you leave your eye and wipe away any bruises or scratches from that area, and then cover it with a bandage after covering the eye itself.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae earum est, ut stringat infirmus collum suum cum uitta.	 The quality of their phlebotomy is such that they raise (or pull) the sick man's head back with a stick
Deinde phlebotoma eas: et tu sis stans super caput eius.	 Afterwards, the phlebotomist should place himself above his patient's head.
Et fiat phlebotomia secundum transuersum ad longitudinem parum, cum phlebotomo paruo, lato parumper, nam in loco non est caro.	 The phlebotomist must perform it downward and forward along the length of the stick, using a small quantity of phlebo [or perhaps phlem] on the end of the stick, so that he may not touch any part which is precious
Si enim phlebotomus est subtilis extremitatis, fortasse frangitur.	 If the phlebotomist's stick is too thin, it will break.
Deinde fac currere ex sanguine quantum est tibi necesse.	 After that, draw out from his blood according to necessity.
Et pone super eas cotum, et stringe eas nocte una, et solue eas.	 And place him above them and pull them up once at night and release them.
¶ De phlebotomia uenarum Nasi.	 The work of phlebotomy is done.
Venae autem Nasi phlebotomia, est conferens ad febrem acutam, et sodam uehementem, et aegritudines faciei, sicut hemigraneam, et rubedinem quae accidit in facie: praecipue quando est antiqua.	 Venous phlebotomy is a treatment for the fever and cold sweat that causes redness of the face, just as hemigration does [or perhaps, hemorrhage], especially when it is ancient [old].
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut stringat infirmus collum suum.	 The quality or effectiveness of their phlebotomy is such that they raise up the sick man's head with a stick.
Deinde tene nasum eius manu tua sinistra, et accipe phlebotomum subtilem, longum: et fige eum in medio leporis ipsius, inter illud quod distinguit nasum secundum rectitudinem.	 Afterwards, hold his nose with your left hand and take a thin stick of phlebo (or perhaps phlem). Press the end of it into the middle of his ribs where you distinguished his nose according to its line
Quoniam uena non apparet sensui illic, et quia sanguis incipit fluere statim.	 When one side does not show itself to him at that place because the blood starts flowing immediately.
Et oportet, ut ultimes manum tuam cum phlebotomo parumper: et facias currere ex sanguine secundum necessitatem tuam.	 And you should take it from his blood according to your necessity with a little phlebo on the end of the stick.
Deinde liga ipsam nocte una.	 And pull her up once at night and release her.
Ipsa enim restauratur uelociter.	 It will be restored immediately.
¶ De phlebotomia uenarum Guidegi.	 The work of phlebotomy is done.
Duarum uero Guidegi phlebotomiae iuuamentum, est ad constrictionem anhelitus, et incaeptionem leprae, et aegritudines melancholicas, et impetiginem et ulcera mala, et corrodentibus, id est, herpetibus estiomenis.	 The other kind of phlebotomy is a treatment for the itchiness and itching in leprosy, melancholy sadness, jaundice, ulcers caused by worms or snakes, and corrosion of flesh from bites.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae earum est ut stringat infirmus sub utrisque in collo suo cum ligamento: et stet artifex super caput infirmi, et infirmus sit sedens super sedem.	 The quality or effectiveness of their phlebotomy is such that they tie him up with a cord on both sides to his head and stay the artist above his head while he lies down under [his] belly.
Deinde phlebotoma uenam ad longitudinem phlebotomia ampla parumper.	 After making an incision at the length of the phlebotomy, it is wide
Deinde extrahe ex sanguine quantitatem temperatam, aut secundum illud quod uides ex necessitate quae est ad illud.	 Afterwards extract from the blood a certain quantity, either according to what you desire or as necessary
Deinde fac similiter de uena alia.	 Afterwards make in the same way with another vein.
Postea solue ligamentum, et stringe duas uenas strictura media: ut non praefocetur infirmus.	 After that, tie a ligature on both sides of the middle third of the veins to prevent them from collapsing.
Et dimitte eam usque mane.	 And let go at the beginning of it.
Sanatur enim uulnus.	 Clean out the wound.
¶ De phlebotomia uenarum Algeberich.	 The phlebotomy of veins by Albucasis
Venae autem Algeberich phlebotomiae iuuamentum est: quia confert ad alcolam in ore, et corruptionem gingiuae: et ulcera mala: et fissuras labiorum, et ulcera mala, etiam quae sunt in naso, et in circumitu eius.	 The equipment for phlebotomy by Albucasis is this: one puts a piece of cloth into the mouth and cleans out the tongue, wipes away the blood clot, cleanses out ulcers, makes cuts on the veins, makes cuts on the ulcers as well those in the nose and around his face.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae earum est, ut facias sedere infirmum coram te: et stringe collum eius cum uitta.	 The quality of the phlebotomy for them is such that you should do no harm to a sick person in front of you; and tie his neck with a rope.
Deinde reuolue labium eius, et aspice ad duas uenas: quarum una est a dextera labii, et secunda a sinistra eius: et demonstratio utriusque est per nigredinem ambarum.	 Afterwards return to the mouth of him and look towards two veins; one is on his right hand, and the other on his left side; and demonstration by means of both sides through the darkness is done.
