Quod si eueniat Spondilibus dorsi simile illius, et uis scire, an sanetur etiam, an non: tunc considera ad pedes eius: tunc si uides quod mollificati sunt, et accidit in eis illud quod accidit in manibus: deinde quando iacet super dorsum suum, egreditur uentositas et egestio absque uoluntate: et quando resupinatur super uentrem suum, egreditur egestio sine uoluntate: et quando resupinatur super dorsum suum, et uult mingere, et non potest: tunc scias, quia est mortale.	 When the thumbbones of the left hand are broken similarly and you know how to treat them or not, then consider its position in relation to your feet; if when they become loose you know that it has happened as well, but when this occurs in the hands - then at that point you understand that it is mortal.
Non ergo labores in curatione eius.	 Do not exert yourself unnecessarily while caring for him.
Si uero non accidit ei aliquid ex illo, res est leuior.	 If the above did not cause any damage to him, then it is better (or: less harmful).
Et curatio eius quod accidit ex illo est, ut coneris sedationem apostematis calidi: ita, ut ponas super Spondilem attritam oleum rosatum solum: aut cum uitellis oui assati.	 And the care he received for what happened to him is that you administer a soothing ointment with sweet oil and warm sun; or if you want to, give food (nourishment).
Pone super ipsam illud aliquotiens in die, donec quando sedatur apostema calidum: tum pone super locum unum ex emplastris confortantibus, exiccantibus, et stringe super ipsum cum ligamento: et praecipe infirmo, ut utatur quiete et tranquillitate.	 Place this on the spot every now and then during the day until it is soaked with soothing ointment from the cold; if you want to stretch it a bit between the fingers, warm it up gently, hold onto it with a cord and make sure that there's no loosening of the skin or any injury.
Nec dormiat super partem cum qua inuenit dolorem, donec sanetur.	 Do not let him rest on his part where he received the pain until he is healed.
Quod si accidit apud attritionem ossis sathaiatum, aut aliquid quod iam separatum fit ex eo: tunc oportet, ut seces super cutem, et auferas illud.	 If something has happened to the left thumbbone and it is separated from him - then you must take off his clothing and get that thing out of there.
Deinde aggrega duo labia uulneris, si est magnum, cum sutura.	 Then close both lips together with a stitch if they are large enough (large enough to cover the thumb).
Deinde cura ipsum cum aliquo incarnatiuo, ex unguentis, donec sanetur.	 Then care for him with some warm oil until he is healed.
Si uero frangitur postremum ossis alhausos, et est finis caudae: tunc oportet, ut intromittas pollicem manus sinistrae in anum, et aeques os fractum manu altera, secundum quod possibile est, et secunda aequatione.	 If the last bone of his left hand is broken and there's no other way out - then you should put your thumb into his mouth with your right hand as well; if that doesn't work for some reason or another, try to break his second tooth from the inside (the one on the opposite side).
Deinde pone super ipsum, et aufer ipsum: et cura uulnus cum curatione quae praecessit, donec sanetur.	 Then put it back onto him and get that thing off; and care for his wound along with what came before while he is being healed.
¶ De restauratione Anchae.	 Of Restoring Ankh
Caput XI.	 Of Removing The Skull
Raro franguntur ossa Ancharum.	 Rare bones are broken.
Quod si franguntur, tunc fractura eorum non est, nisi comminutio in extremitatibus ipsorum: et scinduntur in longitudine, et declinantur ad interiora: et accidit infirmo dolor in loco, et punctura: et stupescit crus quod frangitur.	 If the bones are broken, then the fracture is not complete unless there is a comminution to the extremities of them; and they divide into lengthways, and fall towards their interiors; and there happens a weakness in pain at its place, and perforation: and it makes the hand tremble when it is broken.
Et restauratio quidem eius est, ut extendas manum tuam super ipsum, donec stes super fracturam qualiter est figura eius.	 The restoration of them indeed is as if you place your hand upon him and stop the breaking just like its figure.
Quod si fractura est in extremitatibus eius tantum, tunc aequa illam fracturam, secundum quod praeparatur tibi ex aequatione, donec assimiletur figurae suae naturali.	 If the bone is broken only at its extremities, then you make it equal to that fracture as much as what was prepared for you from an equation and until the figure of his own naturalness is similar.
Si autem fractura est in longitudine, aut iam declinat ad interiora: tunc fac iacere infirmum super uentrem suum, donec praeparetur tibi restauratio illius fracturae.	 If the bone is broken at its length or falls towards its interiors; then you place a weakness upon his middle part and until you prepare for him the restoration of that fracture.
Quando ergo aequaueris ipsam, pone super ipsam emplastrum: deinde pone super ipsam astellam ex ligno, aut ex cute: et stringe strictura super quam non timeas permutationem fracturae, neque remotionem astellae.	 When you make it equal to that, you place upon her the bandage and then the star from wood or skin; and you draw the band tight over what you do not take long enough the permutation of the fracture, nor the removal of the stars.
Et aequa concauitatem illorum cum eo quod impleat eam, donec capiat eam strictura secundum aequalitatem: et praecipe infirmo, ut dormiat super dorsum suum, aut super latus suum sanum.	 And making it equal to that as he extends her bandage so she holds it with the band according to equality; and you place the weakness as he lies down on his back or healthy side.
Si autem accidat ei apostema calidum: tunc cessa ab extensione eius, et ipsius restauratione, donec sedetur apostema calidum: et pone super ipsum quod sedet ipsum, secundum quod praecessit, deinde redi ad restaurationem eius: et stringe ipsum sicut oportet.	 If it happens to him a cold finger; then he stops from its extension and his restoration and until the cold finger rests; and you place upon himself what is seated on itself according to that which preceded, and after that goes back for his restoration, and you draw him as he must be drawn.
Si uero accidit in osse satagie, aut comminuitur, extrahe.	 If it happens to the thighbone or is broken off; then take them away from there.
¶ De restauratione fracturae Adiutorii.	 Of The Aid For Restoration
Caput XII.	 Of The Aid For Removing The Skull.
Adiutorium est illud, quod est inter cubitum usque ad caput Spatulae.	 The aid is what lies between the elbow and the head of the spatula.
Si ergo frangitur, tunc restauratio eius est secundum unum duorum modorum.	 If it is broken, its restoration follows one of two ways
Quorum unus est: ut accipias lignum planum mediae grossitudinis, secundum hanc formam, quae sequitur.	 The first way is to obtain a middle plank with the appropriate size, following this pattern
Et ligentur in duabus extremitatibus duo ligamenta.	 Two ligaments are tied at both ends of it.
Deinde suspendatur ex loco eleuato: et sedeat infirmus super sedem.	 Then, having been suspended from the place where it was broken, he lies down on a bed.
Deinde proiiciat brachium suum fractum super lignum, donec perueniat ad titillicum eius, in cuius medio sit annexa curuitas ligni.	 Then, holding his fractured arm above the plank, until it touches and passes over the middle of it, where it is attached with a bandage
Deinde suspende desuper ipsum aliquid graue, ut extendat ipsum minister ad inferiora.	 Afterwards, he suspends him from above in order to stretch him out gently towards his lower part.
Deinde aequet medicus fracturam manibus suis simul, donec redeat fractura, secundum quod oportet.	 Then the physician stretches both of his arms simultaneously, until he is healed and has regained strength, in accordance with what is necessary.
Et modus alter est, ut resupinetur infirmus super ceruicem suam: et suspende manum eius a collo ipsius cum ligamento.	 Another way is to have the patient lie on his chest so that he hangs over his own leg, and ties one of his hands around his neck with a bandage.
Deinde praecipe duobus ministris, ut teneat unus eorum illud quod est supra fracturam cum manibus suis: et ut alter teneat inferius eius, et extendat unusquisque eorum ad partem suam.	 The two physicians take turns supporting him, one holding on to the side of his head that is above his fracture with both hands and the other holding onto his lower leg and stretching each towards its own side.
Et si uis, ut sit extensio fortior, tunc stringe sub fractura cum ligamento, et supra ipsam cum ligamento alio: et extendat ea unusquisque duorum ministrorum ad duas partes suas.	 And if he wants a stronger stretch, then tie him down at the fracture with one bandage and over it with another; and they each stretch towards two sides of his body.
Si ergo fractura est propinqua extremitati humeri, tunc oportet, ut ponatur unum ligamentum sub titillico, et alterum sub fractura uersus cubitum.	 If the fracture is close to one of the arms, then it must be that a bandage is tied down at the fracture and another over his shoulder.
Et similiter si fractura est propinqua cubito: tunc oportet, ut ponatur ligamentum super illum locum, et super cubitum ipsum.	 If the fracture is close to one of the arms, then it must be that a bandage is tied down at the fracture and another over his shoulder.
Deinde aequa fracturam cum facilitate absque labore, donec quando aequatur fractura secundum quod oportet, et applicatur applicatione bona: tunc stringe eam, si non accidit apostema calidum.	 Afterwards, when the fracture is equal in ease and without labor, until it becomes equal to what is necessary; then tie her down with a bandage if she does not fall off on her own warmth.
Si uero accidit apostema calidum, tunc dimitte stricturam usque ad diem septimum.	 If the fall off of the arm in cold weather occurs earlier than after seven days, then loosen it until after seven days.
Et pone super ipsum lanam succidam imbibitam in aceto et oleo rosato, donec quando quiescit apostema: tunc stringe eam: et modus stringendi eam est, ut ponas emplastrum super fracturam.	 "Strike above the eye with a solution of vinegar and oil mixed; until it falls asleep, then pull it out.
Deinde pone inuolutionem ex panno nouo super emplastrum.	 After striking the mixture on the eye, wipe off the excess using a new cloth.
Deinde aggreget brachium super adiutorium ipsum, et ponat manum suam apertam super humerum suum.	 After wiping away the excess solution, put your arm above it and place your hand open over your own shoulder.
Et pone pannum, et stringe super adiutorium brachium, ut brachium stet loco astellarum: si non prohibet te ab illo aliquid, neque alteretur super te aliquid ex osse fracto.	 And put on the cloth and pull it above your arm so that your arm is in place as a support; if you are not obstructed by something from the other side or behind, nothing should fall upon you from any broken bone.
Quod si times, quod alteretur super te ex osse fracto aliquid, tunc utere astellis: et est, ut ponas super fracturam ipsam astellam quae sit latior et fortior reliquis astellis.	 If that should happen and something falls upon you from a broken bone on the other side or behind, then use this support as an anchor; it is so placed to be higher than all others and stronger in order to hold onto it securely with both hands when needed.
Et ponas inter omnem astellam latitudinem digiti: et sit longitudo astellarum secundum fracturam cum additione trium digitorum ab omni parte.	 And put the support on one side of all the other supports, length-wise with your fingers; the lengths of the supports should be according to their height and with an additional three fingers from every part.
Deinde stringe super astellas strictura quam dixi in principio capituli.	 After that, pull on the supports as I explained at first until you have reached your desired height
Et est, ut sit strictura tua super locum fracturae strictior.	 And it is so that your height should be set above the area of the more restricted fracture.
Et quanto plus elongatur fractura, sit strictura minor.	 The length and strength of the supports will increase as the fracture becomes longer and weaker.
Si ergo uides situm astellarum et stricturam, sicut diximus, in hora qua restauras membrum statim, tunc fac: et si times apostema calidum, tunc dimitte stricturam et astellas usque ad diem septimum, sicut diximus.	 If you wish the supports and tension to be as we described before when you are ready to restore the limb immediately thereafter do this; if something falls on it while it is still cold, then release the tension and all the remaining supports until the end of seven days like I said before.
Deinde considera ligamentum in omnibus tribus diebus, ut non accidat in loco pruritus, aut inflatio, aut prohibeatur cibus peruenire ad membrum, propter dispositionem superfluitatis stricturae.	 After that, consider the ligament for three days to prevent itching or swelling from happening and to be pressed against it by anything with a body part due to the arrangement of the excess tension.
Rectifica ergo illud totum, secundum quod diximus.	 Therefore rectify everything as I have said before.
Si uero es super fiduciam, ut non accidat ex illo aliquid: tunc non soluas ligamentum, nisi post tres dies, aut plus.	 If you are on the edge of falling off due to something from that side, then only release the ligament and after three days at most
Et sit dormitio infirmi super dorsum suum, et manus eius super stomachum suum: et pone sub adiutorio culcitram plenam lana aequaliter.	 The nurse lies on her back and puts one hand over her stomach while holding another hand to her breast with the goal of breastfeeding being filled up equally
Et considera in omni hora noctis, aut diei, ut non soluatur figura membri fracta, aut mollificetur ligamentum.	 And remember during sleep or wakefulness that no broken bone should be fixed and a soft ligature put upon it
Rectifica ergo illud totum uirtute tua.	 Therefore do this with your own skill.
Et pone cibum infirmi secundum ordinem quem praemisimus, ita ut sit cibus subtilis in primis, donec incipiat os stringi: tunc oportet, ut ingrosses cibum eius.	 And the nurse feeds her patient with a spoon according to our rule so that she will first eat something soft and gradually move on to food of other consistencies until it is time for her to begin eating solid foods: at this point she must consume more nourishing food.
De consuetudine enim adiutorii et cruris est, ut stringatur in quadraginta diebus: tunc ergo oportet, ut soluatur, et administretur balneum, et medicetur cum unguentis quae rectificant illud.	 Because of the custom and usage with the spoon it is to be fed for thirty days consecutively; then from this point on it is necessary that she should be fed until her thirst has been satisfied and medicines are applied with ointments which will aid in this.
Quod si fractura fuerit foeda, attrita: tunc non soluas ab ea ligamentum et astellas usque ad quinquaginta dies, et usque ad duos menses.	 If there is a broken bone then she should be fed until that ligature and poultices are applied up to fifty days or two months.
¶ De restauratione fracturae Brachii.	 Of the restoration of arm fracture
Caput XIII.	 Head Thirteen.
Brachium est compositum ex duobus ossibus, quae nominantur duo focilia.	 Arm is composed of two bones called humerus and ulna.
Quorum unum est paruum: et est illud quod sequitur pollicem.	 Of the thumb bone.
Et alterum est magnum, et est illud quod est positum sub paruo ab inferiori parte.	 The other one is large and it is that which is put under a small from below part.
Fortasse ergo frangitur focile maius solum, aut paruum: et fortasse franguntur simul.	 Therefore if the larger thumb bone breaks alone or both are broken simultaneously.
Quando ergo frangitur focile paruum superius, tunc restauratio eius est facilis, et sanatio eius est facilior.	 When therefore a large thumb bone is broken then the restoration and healing of that one is easy and is easier.
Et quando frangitur focile inferius, est fractura eius mala, et sanatio eius difficilis.	 And when the lower thumb bone is broken there was a bad break for him and his healing will be difficult.
Et deterior ea est, quando franguntur duo ossa simul.	 And it is worse if two bones are broken simultaneously.
Si ergo os quod frangitur est focile parum superius, tunc conuenit medico apud restaurationem eius, ut ponat extensionem paruam cum facilitate, donec aequet ipsum.	 If therefore the upper thumb bone breaks then there was a meeting with a doctor for restoration of that one so as to put on a ligature easily and gradually until it is equal in strength.
Si uero focile magnum est illud quod fractum est: tunc oportet, ut ponat stricturam fortiorem ualde.	 If the large thumb bone breaks then there should be applied a stronger ligature.
Et oportet, ut ponat figuram manus apud restaurationem eius, et ipsius extensionem extensam super puluinar.	 "You must place a figure on his restoration and also extend his arm above the pulse.
Et sit pollex manus ad superiora altior omnibus digitis: et sit articularis inferior omnibus digitis, uel reliquis: et infirmus sedens quadratus super seipsum, et sit puluinar coram eo, uel in directo eius, in altitudine, ut non incurrat infirmus laborem.	 "The hand must be extended above all the fingers; and to the inferior articular joint with all the fingers, or others: and if a person is lying flat on their back, have his elbow near them, or directly behind them at an appropriate height so that they do not tire from work.
Deinde extendat minister Brachium ab inferiori parte, aut manu sua, aut cum ligamento.	 "Then the assistant should extend their arm from below part, either with their hand, or using a cord.
Et minister alius extendat desuper similiter.	 "The other assistant should also extend similarly from above.
Deinde aequet medicus os, donec reducat ipsum secundum meliorem figuram quam potest.	 "Then the physician adjusts his mouth to reduce him as much as possible according to better appearance.
Quod si in fractura ossis sunt satagiae, tunc conare reducere omne frustum in loco suo uirtute tua.	 "If there is a fracture of the bones then the assistant should gently move aside any broken parts with your strength in their place.
Si uero apparet in eo sathaiatum separatum, et pungit cutem, et non est tibi spes in restauratione eius: tunc finde super ipsum, et aufer ipsum secundum modum quem diximus in eis quae praemissa sunt.	 "If there is any swelling on his side then gently pull it off and the finger wound should not be a hope for restoration; then find its upper part and remove it according to what we have said about those that are missing.
Si autem fractura est cum uulnere, ego iam feci ad illud capitulum singulare, ergo accipe curationem illius inde.	 "However if there is a fracture with injury I did make the one particular finger for this end; therefore take care of it from that point.
Quod si accidat in principio tuae restaurationis apostema calidum, tunc line pannum cum caeroto facto ex oleo rosato, et caera alba, et sit medium inter spissitudinem et subtilitatem: et stringe pannum super ipsum strictura subtili, donec quando sedatur apostema: tunc remoue caerotum, et pone emplastrum praeparatum ex puluere molendini cum albumine oui.	 "If you begin the restoration with a cold hand then take a linen cloth soaked in oil and white, it should be medium between hardness and softness; and tightly wrap this on his head so that when he is done the bandage will not slip off; then remove the wet bandanna and put one prepared plaster on top using flour mixed with egg whites.
Deinde pone astellas, et sit astella quae ponitur super fracturam ipsam latior parumper, et fortior.	 "Then you put oil on it so that there is a light oil spot next to the fracture which is larger and stronger than the bandage itself.
Et scias, quod numerus astellarum Brachii est sex in pluribus dispositionibus: siue sit fractura in focili uno, aut in duobus focilibus simul.	 "You know that the number of fingers on one arm is six depending on how many you are using; either there be a fracture in only one or two places simultaneously.
Deinde pone stricturam tuam super locum fracturae fortiorem et uehementiorem, et aliquanto plus cum strictura ad superiora fracturae, aut ad inferiora eius: aut pone stricturam molliorem strictura eius parumper, secundum quod praecessit rememoratio eius in principio capituli.	 "Then you put your bandage tighter to the stronger and weaker place of the fracture; also some amount more with the upper or lower one depending on what is written at first.
Et sint panni qui inuoluuntur super fracturam, panni lenes, humidi: et non sint duri, asperi.	 "The veins that are squeezed from above a fracture should be covered with wet, soft pads; and they should not be dried up or hardened.
Et sit filum quo stringitur ex lino proprie, medium inter subtile et grossum, sicut narrauimus.	 "Let the thread used to tie the ligature from linen be its own, in between fine and coarse; just as we have tied it with linen.
Et considera membrum et ligamentum post dies.	 "Consider the membrane and ligament after a day has passed.
Quod si accidat aliquid cuius rectificatio sit necessaria, sicut pruritus qui accidit membro: tunc oportet, ut embroces membrum cum aqua calefacta, donec quiescat ille pruritus, et dimittas membrum non constrictum, donec quiescat, deinde itera stricturam.	 "If what you apply is necessary for its correction, just as itching applies to a limb: then let the membrane be rubbed with heated water until the itch ceases and the member is not constricted; after this, repeat tightening.
Quod si strictura iam mollificata est, et os iam remotum, et similia illis: tunc rectifica illud totum uirtute tua, et considera iterum.	 "If the tightness has already been softened and removed, like these things, then correct it entirely with your own strength; consider what is to come.
Nam si nutrimentum prohibetur peruenire ad membrum, propter superfluitatem stricturae, tunc oportet, ut mollifices ipsum parumper, et dimittas ipsum aliquot diebus, donec currat ad ipsum nutrimentum, deinde stringe ipsum.	 "If the nourishment is prohibited from reaching the membrane due to excess tightness of the skin, then you should let it be softened more and remove it every few days until the nourishment reaches it; after that tighten it.
Si autem non accidit infirmo aliquid eorum quae diximus, tunc non oportet, ut soluatur, nisi post uiginti dies, aut circiter hos.	 "But if what we have spoken of does not come to the aid of those things, then it is not necessary for you to make them wet unless after one day or in alternate days.
Deinde suspendatur manus infirmi ad collum eius.	 "After that, let your hand be suspended lightly on its neck.
Et sit collum eius aequale, et custodiatur uirtute sua a motibus agitatiuis.	 "And let the neck of it remain equal and be guarded by your strength against being agitated with motion.
Et fac eum dormire super dorsum suum.	 "Let him sleep on its back.
Et scias, quod haec fractura in triginta diebus, aut in triginta duobus diebus restauratur: et fortasse restauratur in uigintiocto diebus.	 "You know that this fracture is restored after thirty days or two thirty-day periods; and perhaps it may be restored within one hundred twenty days.
Totum illud est secundum dispositiones complexionum, et dispositiones uirtutis.	 "Everything was according to the dispositions of its color and strength.
¶ De restauratione fracturarum Manus.	 "Of how fractures should be healed by hand.
Caput XIIII.	 "Chapter 12: Of Fractures Healed by Hand
Scias, quod pectini Manus, et nodis digitorum raro accidit fractura.	 "You know that the hands of a man and the fingers of his hand are rarely injured in fracture.
Et non accidit ei, nisi attritio multotiens.	 "And it does not happen to him except when there is excessive weariness.
Quando ergo accidit plantae fractura, aut attritio: tunc oportet, ut sedeat infirmus quadratus: et coram eo sit sedes secundum aequalitatem.	 When therefore bones are broken or diseased (i.e., when a bone is fractured or decayed), then the afflicted limb should be placed in a square frame and the seat on top of it shall be level, as if seated.
Deinde pone Manum eius super eam extensam.	 Then he places his arm above that same frame, extended.
Deinde extendat minister ossa fracta, et aequet ea medicus, donec quando coniunguntur coniunctione bona.	 Then he extends the fractured bones and aligns them as if joined by a good union.
Tunc oportet, ut ponat emplastrum et stuppam, si non accidat apostema calidum.	 At that time, it is necessary to place a plaster on his arm and bandage (it) should the hot water have been applied first.
Deinde pone astellam desuper secundum quantitatem loci: et tu iam inuoluisti eam in panno lini.	 Then he places an arrow above it according to its quantity, and you just finished with that in your hand?
Si autem fractura est ad inferiora circiter uentrem plantae, tunc fac simile spherae ex panno: et praecipe infirmo, ut coartet super eam cum planta sua fracta: deinde stringatur cum panno longo.	 If the bone is fractured from below and around it there is no room for plants to grow, then he makes a sphere out of cloth and wraps up the affected limb with that so that the broken limb may heal along with its own plant (or if you prefer: so that the severed limb heals in contact with itself). Then wrap it well with long cloth.
Et sit astella ex corio, in quo sit lenitas, ut applicetur corium cum corpore plantae: et stringe eam, secundum quod oportet.	 The arrow is from a quiver, which has the softness that you need to apply it on the surface of the plants' body and wrap her with long cloth according to what needs to be done.
Si autem fractura est ad exteriora, tunc oportet: ut ponas astellam desuper, et astellam aliam ab inferiori in planta: et sit manus aperta recta.	 If the bone is fractured from outside (i.e., if a limb has been cut off), then it should be placed above and another arrow below the plant to its side; and leave your hand open straight.
Deinde pone stricturam, sicut reuoluitur manus: et extende inter digitos cum ligamento.	 Then he places a bandage as before with his hand extended between them (the fingers) and binds it together with the ligature.
Quod si accidat fractura alicui nodorum digitorum, tunc si est pollex, aequetur secundum quod oportet.	 If he breaks any of the bones of his finger(s), then align them as necessary (or if you prefer: according to what is required).
Deinde stringatur cum planta: et si amas, pone ei astellam rectam, paruam: ut eleuetur fractura, et non moueatur.	 Then he wraps it with a plant and places an arrow at the right side (or if you prefer: at its head) to support the fracture so that it does not move around.
Si autem fractura est reliquis digitis, sicut medio, et indici, aut auriculari, et anulari, tunc aequetur, et ligetur cum digito sano qui sequitur eum: aut ligentur omnes secundum continuationem: et est melius.	 If any of the other fingers are broken as well, align them in sequence and bind them with the healthy finger(s) according to the connection; or bind them all together by extending them one after another (and it is better).
Aut pone super ipsum astellam paruam, sicut diximus in pollice.	 Upon placing the probe above the object, remove it as we have shown for the finger
Et considera in restauratione tua, et post ipsam dispositionem apostematis calidi: et oppone cum eo quod oportet, quando accidit aliquid ex illo, secundum quod iteratur eius narratio.	 After your restoration has taken place and after you have placed the object in its correct position with the warm probe, remove it when something is removed from that location following the same procedure as we previously described for removing a finger.
¶ De restauratione fracturae Coxae.	 Of the repair of broken leg
Caput XV.	 Chapter 15.
OS Coxae multotiens frangitur, et declaratur sensui: quoniam conuertitur ad interiorem et posteriorem partem.	 The knee is often fractured and the statement of this fact is obvious because it is turned inwards towards its interior and outwards towards its exterior.
Et restauratio eius fit ita, quod stringitur ligamentum supra fracturam, et ligamentum aliud sub fractura.	 And its repair is made in such a way that the ligament above the fracture is drawn tight, while another ligament below the fracture.
Et infirmus prostretur super faciem suam.	 He stretches out over his face.
Deinde extendat omne ligamentum minister ad partem suam secundum aequalitatem: et hoc, quando est fractura in medio ossis.	 Afterwards he extends all the ligaments towards her face equally and this when there is a fracture of the bones.
Si autem est fractura propinqua radici Coxae, tunc sit ligamentum ad partem pectinis, ut cadat extensio ad sursum: et ligamentum aliud sub fractura.	 However if there is a fracture close to the root of the knee, then the ligament towards the face falls away and the other ligament below it.
Et sic similiter si est fractura propinqua genu, tunc sit ligamentum propinquum genu, ut sit extensio ad inferiora.	 And similarly if there is a fracture close to the knee joint, then he extends towards the lower part of his leg.
Deinde aequet medicus os utriusque manibus suis, donec reducat ipsum secundum similitudinem figurae naturalis: et coniugatur os coniunctione bona.	 Afterwards the surgeon equalizes both his hands with their own saliva until he reduces him according to the similarity of the natural shape: and joins them together by a good union.
Tunc oportet, ut ponas emplastrum et stricturam, si non accidit membro apostema.	 Then you have placed the probe and tightened it if no finger was removed.
Quod si accidat in eo apostema: tunc dimitte ipsum diebus aliquot, donec sedetur apostema calidum, deinde redi ad curationem tuam.	 If something was taken from that location, then you release him for a certain number of days until he is cold enough and return to your care.
Strictura autem eius ita sit.	 The tightening of his should be as follows.
Oportet ut inuoluas super fracturam imema duram, id est, bindam: et dupla eam bis, aut ter: et remaneat ex ea superfluitas.	 It is permitted to pass a probe over the fracture that may be broken through it, and fasten this twice or three times securely: excess should not remain attached by it.
Deinde inuolue crus, donec perueniat calcaneus apud radicem natis.	 Afterwards he descends until his heel reaches near its root.
Et intromitte filum longum inter Coxam et crus prope genu ad inferiora, et ueniant extremitates fili a superiori parte duarum partium.	 And he enters between the knee and leg towards the lower part of both of them.
Deinde reuolue super Crus et Coxam quod superfluit ex alimema.	 Then apply excess fat from the side of the thigh
Deinde pone super Coxam in loco fracturae ipsius astellas, et pone ex eis astellam unam super os cruris.	 Then place the bone fragments on the hip socket and one star over each knee
Deinde imple uacuitates inter crus et coxam cum pannis lenibus, ut aequetur strictura.	 Then wrap the thigh and upper leg in linen strips, so that they may be tied together tightly.
Deinde incipe cum strictura forti a medio super locum fracturae tribus inuolutionibus, aut quatuor.	 Begin with the tying of three or four strips around the fracture site at mid-length, and continue to wrap them tight around the thigh and upper leg.
Et quanto plus elongaris cum ligamento a loco fracturae, sit strictura tua minor et mollior, et lenior.	 And as you wrap more tightly with one strip towards the fracture site, make your knot looser and longer, so that it may be easier to apply pressure over time.
Deinde intende ad duas extremitates fili, quod tu intromisisti inter coxam et crus.	 Then intend for two extremities of thread, as you crossed between the thigh and lower leg.
Liga ergo cum utrisque tres astellas quae sunt desuper.	 Tie then with three strips that are above
Deinde uade cum duabus extremitatibus fili ad inferiora, donec peruenias ad cauillam pedis.	 Then go downward towards the foot as you tie two of them to make a knot in your ankle.
Et cum utrisque stringe etiam extremitates astellarum a parte altera: ut non remoueatur ligamentum ex loco suo.	 And with both strips and those above tied, such that the other part remains unremoved from its place.
Deinde dimitte stricturam super illud, dum permanet, ita quod non accidat membro corrosio, neque apostema, neque inflatio, et similia eis.	 Then release your knot when it remains there such that neither the member nor any other thing comes to harm as a result of its loosening and relaxing.
Quod si accidat aliquid ex illo.	 If anything goes wrong with this,
Propera ergo cum solutione eius, et rectifica illud quod accidit inde totum, secundum quod diximus multotiens.	 Therefore go back to your solution and rectify what went wrong immediately and as described above many times.
Si uero in osse est frustum ex osse quod pungat: tunc oportet, ut aeques illud, si est tibi possibile.	 If the bone is broken by another bone, then let you set it so that they are equal if possible.
Et si non, finde super illud, et remoue illud: et cura cum eo cuius praecessit rememoratio, donec sanetur.	 And if not, find the other one and remove it from there; remember with whom you preceded until you are cured.
Et quandoque stringitur haec fractura Coxae, praeter quod addantur ei astellae, sicut diximus in adiutorio et brachio.	 And when the thigh fracture is tied like this, as we have described it to help and arm;
Verumtamen in restauratione eius taliter fracta, non accidit infirmo claudicatio.	 However, while tying his fractures in that manner no impairment of movement occurred.
Et si restauratur sola, praeter quod applicetur ei crus alterum, tunc necesse est, ut claudicet ille cuius est, semper.	 And if restored alone without the other leg, then it is necessary to let him who has been impaired walk in turn always.
Et scias, quod Coxa stringitur in quinquaginta diebus, uel additur parum, aut minuitur parum: totum illud est secundum diuersitatem complexionum, et reliquarum dispositionum.	 The hip is stretched for fifty days or added with a few days, but it can be shortened by the same number of days. It's like that because of different constitution and dispositions of limbs.
¶ De restauratione fracturae Rotulae genu.	 On the restoration of the broken leg (tibia).
Caput XVI.	 Section 16
Scias, quod Rotulae genu raro accidit fractura, sed accidit ei attritio multotiens.	 It is known that a rare occurrence of the tibia breaking is a result of excessive effort or injury to it.
Si uero accidit ei fractura, tunc non nisi aut fissura, aut foramen in partibus suis.	 If broken by the same reason as before (either a fissure or a hole), then the bone will heal without an opening on its own parts.
Et est illud cum uulnere, et absque uulnere.	 It is also like that with excessive heat and without excessive cold.
Et statur super illud totum cum sensu.	 And it grows above all of these things with awareness.
Et restauratio eius est ita, ut aequetur quod disruptum est ex partibus eius cum digitis, donec aggregetur, et coniungatur secundum quod possibile est ex aequatione et facilitate, et fabricatione.	 The restoration of the above is like that in order to restore what has been disrupted by its own parts with the fingers and continue to be united according to how possible it is from an equation and ease, and made
Deinde pone emplastrum ex farina sisami, uel molendini, cum albumine oui: et pone super ipsum astellam rotundam, si indiges illa: et stringe desuper strictura conueniente ad illud.	 Then it is smeared with the skin of sesame oil or groundnut paste and placed over this above, making a round star if desired: and tighten above so that it comes down to match the above.
Deinde considera omnes dispositiones quas narrauimus in reliquis fracturis: sicut apostema calidum, et similia illi: ita, ut opponas omni accidenti cum eo quod conuenit ei, donec sanetur.	 Then consider all the dispositions that we mentioned on other fractures as cold hands and similar things to them: so that you may oppose everything with him in how he was able to recover from anything, until it is healed.
¶ De restauratione fracturae Cruris.	 On the restoration of a broken leg (crus).
Caput XVII.	 Section 17
Scias, quod Cruri sunt duo ossa, quorum unum est grossum, et nominatur nomine Cruris: et alterum subtile, et nominatur Focile.	 It is known that the legs are two bones of which one is large and called the crus (the knee) and the other subtle and called the tibia (one bone).
Et accidit utrisque ex speciebus fracturae quod accidit duobus ossibus brachii: et propter illud fit restauratio eius, sicut restauratio brachii aequaliter, et operatio est una.	 And the tibia and crus are broken by two different types of fractures in both arms' bones because of that there is an equal restoration for them as for the arm's bone: so it is one operation.
Quod si franguntur duo ossa simul, conuertitur Crus ad omnes partes.	 If the tibia and the crus are broken at the same time, then they become connected to each other in every part.
Et si frangitur os subtilius, conuertitur Crus ad anteriorem partem.	 And if a subtle bone breaks it becomes connected to the front side.
Et si frangitur os grossius, inuenis illud inferius: et est ex eis quae non occultantur tibi.	 "If you break one of your ribs on the top, this will lead to injury below; and it is from those that are not hidden to you.
Deinde administra extensionem, et aequationem, et ligationem astellarum secundum illud aequaliter.	 "Then apply an extension, balance (or equilibrium), and ligature of the stars in accordance with this balance.
Verumtamen oportet, si fractura Cruris est fractura foeda, habens sethagie multa: ut sit extensio minor, et lenior alleuiatione tua.	 "However, if there is a fracture of the ribs, it being a severe injury; so that its extension may be less than full and to the lesser extent.
Et in Crure quidem est ex operatione quiddam super brachium: et est, ut quando tu aequas astellas, et comples omnem operationem tuam, tunc accipe duas fascias ex ligno pini, quod administratur in fabricatione solariorum quod ponitur sub tabulis: et fiunt ex spatulis palmae: et elige ex eis quibus est grossitudo parua, et neque sint ex minutis: et sit longitudo earum secundum longitudinem Cruris a genu usque inferius.	 "And indeed in the ribs is from an operation of some over the arm; and it is so when you have equal stars, and complete all your operations; then take two cords of pine wood, which is used in the manufacture of the sun's work, placed under boards: and they are done with palm twigs. And choose those who are superior, and not from minute ones; and their length should be according to the length of the ribs, down to below.
Deinde inuolue super unamquamque pannum duabus inuolutionibus secundum longitudinem eius.	 "Then apply over a single piece two solutions in accordance with its length.
Et pone unam partem Cruris a parte una, et alteram a parte altera: et sint ex genu usque inferius pedis.	 "And place one part of the ribs on another, and then place another on another; they are done from the knee down to below.
Deinde liga duas fascias in tribus locis ex duabus extremitatibus et medio.	 "Then ligate two cords at three places with two extremities and a middle one.
Cum enim strictura prohibetur, Crus declinat ad dextram et sinistram, et stat statione bona.	 "Since the restriction is prohibited, the ribs decline to the right and left, and standing in a good position.
Et iam quidem administretur cunabulum ex ligno secundum longitudinem Cruris, et ponatur in eo Crus, ut conseruet ipsum a motu.	 "And indeed, the cuñas (or wedges) of wood are to be applied according to the length of the ribs, and placed into them the ribs so that they can help it with motion.
Et plurimum quidem oportet, ut facias illud in fractura quando cum ea est uulnus proprie.	 "And above all else is needed, so that you make this when there is a fracture as well.
Deinde considera Crus in omni die, et stude cum eo studio ultimo ab apostemate, aut inflatione, aut reliquis aliis.	 "Then consider the ribs every day and study them with him, at the very last of his work from the apostles or others; either by raising it, or by something else.
Si ergo accidit aliquid ex illis, tunc oppone ei cum eo quod oportet, usquequo sanetur, si Deus uoluerit.	 "If therefore anything happens from them, then you should bind him with it, as long as he wills.
De fractura ossium Pedis, et Digitorum.	 "Of fractures of the arms and hands.
Caput XVIII.	 On the eighth head
Calcaneo quidem non accidit fractura penitus.	 The heelbone is not broken by a fracture of the foot.
Ossibus uero Pedis accidit quandoque fractura, et Digitis parum etiam accidit fractura: et non accidit eis nisi attritio in pluribus dispositionibus.	 A bone in the foot is broken by a fracture when there are several fractures and not just one; it does not happen to them unless there is attrition due to multiple impacts or blows.
Quod si accidit ossibus Pedis fractura, et uides illa ossa sublimari super se adinuicem, tunc ponat infirmus Pedem suum super terram praeparatam, sicut ambulans.	 If the footbone is broken, you will see that bone raised above itself to its own arm; then it supports the foot over the ground as a stretcher does.
Deinde sta tu, et pone Pedem tuum super illud quod eleuatur ex illis ossibus: postea preme, uel calca eam: et aequa ipsam, donec redeat in locis suis.	 Then you stand there and put the foot on top of that which was raised by them; afterwards praise it, or call it by its name, and equal it with these places: until then she remains in her own place.
Deinde pone emplastrum, et stuppam desuper: et pone sub uentre Pedis tabulam paruam, cui sint duo capita plana.	 Then you support the stretcher on top of that; and put a small platform under the foot with two flat feet beneath it, which have been given to him by God.
Deinde stringe eam cum Pede strictura decenti, postquam tu inuoluis eam cum pannis, et reliquis quibus indiget.	 Then you tie her with a decent rope; after that you hold her tightly with the cloth, and others to whom she is subject
Cum ergo praetereunt ei tres dies, aut quatuor, tunc solue ligamentum.	 After three or four days then loose the cord.
Nam tu inuenies ossa aequata, siue sint fracta, aut sint dislocata.	 You will equalize those bones if they are fractured, dislocated, or just moved around.
Operatio ergo in eis est, sicut uides.	 The operation is performed upon them as you see it.
Si autem franguntur aliqui digiti, tunc restaura eos, et aequa ipsos secundum quod narraui tibi in restauratione digitorum manus.	 If any fingers are broken then restore those and equalize them according to what I told you about restoring the hands.
Deinde pone digito tuo astellam secundum longitudinem digiti, et sit latior eo parumper: deinde pone sub Pede hanc tabulam quam narraui tibi, et stringe eam strictura decenti.	 Then you put your own finger on the platform according to its length and make it longer than that; afterwards put under the foot the platform I told you about, and tie her with a decent rope.
Si uero quod frangitur ex ossibus est duo, aut tria, aut plus, tunc pone super omnem digitum astellam suae quantitatis, inuolutam in panno lini: et stringe tabulam in inferiori Pedis: et sit stans super unum capitum tabulae extra uentrem Pedis, ut teneat retentione bona.	 If the bones from which that finger was broken are two or three or more then you put on top of every one of his fingers a platform of its quantity lined with cloth; and tie her to under the foot: and let her be standing over one footboard outside the foot so that it holds by good retention.
Et conuenit tibi, ut non obliuiscaris, quin consideres omnia quae dixi tibi in reliquis fracturis ex accidentibus quae diximus: et oppone omni accidenti cum eo quod oportet.	 And I will tell you that the one who knows all things which I have said to you about the others broken and injured from accidents should not neglect any of them, but oppose every accident with him as it is necessary.
¶ De fractura Vuluae mulieris, et ossis pectinis, et uirgae uiri.	 On broken bones of women and men
Caput XIX.	 On the head
Quando frangitur Vulua mulieris, tunc fac eam sedere quadratam.	 When a woman's jaw is broken, then seat her in a square posture
Deinde inclina eam ad partem dorsi ipsius parumper, et teneatur retro.	 Then incline her towards the back of her neck and hold her with both hands behind.
Deinde impleat obstetrix Vuluam eius coto, donec impleat eam: et fiat in Vulua ex eo sicut sphera.	 After this is done by an obsteratrix (a woman trained to break bones), then lay the woman on her stomach with both hands holding her body down and let a ball of cloth be placed under her neck as if supporting it like a sphere.
Deinde concutiatur mulier, et eleua dorsum eius paulatim.	 The woman is laid flat (on the ground), and the bones are gently pulled towards each other.
Illud enim cotum egreditur, donec fiat ante portam Vuluae sicut sphera, et os fractum redit.	 This will then be supported by a ball of cloth as before so that her head is lowered and the bones are broken.
Deinde pone puluillum super dorsum eius.	 Then the man takes hold of her with both hands, holding her down on her back and breaks her bones again.
Quando ergo uult mingere, remoueat cotum cum facilitate, deinde mingat: et reduc ipsum secundum modum, quo intromisisti ipsum in primis: deinde redeat ad puluillum suum primum.	 Therefore he takes her down gently and moves with ease back to where you broke the bones before; then break them again as they were broken originally, then releases his first hold so that he can grasp it (his body) once more.
Faciat illud septem diebus, aut circiter, os ipsum enim restauratur.	 He will perform this seven days in a row or alternate days until the bones are restored to their original state.
Et si uis, accipe uesicam ouis, et stringe super foramen eius cannulam arundinis, et intromitte uesicam totam in Vuluam eius.	 And if it is not possible, take hold of her hair with both hands and pull the cloth from beneath her neck until she has been pulled all the way up into her vulva (her vagina).
Deinde suffla in cannulam cum uirtute, donec infletur uesica intra Vuluam, fractura enim redit.	 After this is done by pulling on the cloth with great force until the hair and cloth are all inside her vulva (her vagina), then she will be broken again.
Deinde impleatur cum coto, et stet aliquot diebus, secundum quod narrauimus, donec sanetur.	 After this is done by an obstetrical woman with a cloth and held for several days until it heals as we have described previously.
Et quando frangitur os Pectinis uiri, aut mulieris, tunc administra in restauratione eius, et ipsius aequatione illud quod narrauimus in osse Anchae.	 And when the bones of men or women are broken then he administers to restore them and arranges them as we described before for the Anchae bone.
Et non occultatur rectum in his fracturis propinquis, quae parum contingunt, praecipue cui est quiddam studii, uel usus.	 And it is not hidden from view that the anus may be injured by those whose strength fails them, but primarily for those with some study or use of anatomy.
Et intellige librum meum istum multum, quoniam fractura ipsa significat tibi in pluribus dispositionibus uiam rectam in restauratione sui, et strictura sui: intellige ergo.	 "I have learned much from this book because its fracture means to you the right way in many dispositions for restoration of your own and restriction of your own; therefore understand.
In Virga autem uiri quando frangitur, accipe guttur anseris: et intromitte uirgam in ipso.	 "When the bowstring of a man breaks, take the goose-quill [pen] and write it on that place.
Deinde pone super ipsum inuolutionem ex panno, et inuoluatur, et dimittatur tribus diebus, aut circiter eos, et sanabitur, si Deus uoluerit.	 Then apply a solution with a cloth to it and let it be soaked; then let it be poured out three days or around them if God wills.
¶ De restauratione fracturae ossium, quando est cum uulnere.	 For the restoration of the bone when there is a fracture accompanying a wound
Caput XX.	 Head XX.
Conuenit ei cui accidit fractura cum uulnere, praecipue si est magnum, sicut os coxae, aut adiutorii, aut simile illi, ut properes, et phlebotomes ipsum statim: si attestantur tibi conditiones phlebotomiae, sicut praemisimus.	 It happened to him who had a fracture accompanying the wound, especially if it is large like that of the nose or cheeks or assistant's fingers, so they are brought close and quickly applied by you as we did; but when conditions for phlebotomy [bleeding] are present, do so.
Quod si uulnus effluit sanguinem, tunc oportet, ut properes ad abscisionem eius, ita ut puluerizes super ipsum zegi tritum: si non est tibi praesens aliud.	 If a wound bleeds from the blood then you must bring them close to making an incision for him; so that you will squeeze over his cheek as we did.
Deinde incipe restaurare fracturam in illo eodem die: et non postponas illud, si non accidit apostema.	 After this initiate the restoration of the fracture on the same day and do not delay it if an assistant is not present.
Si uero accidit apostema calidum, tunc dimitte restaurationem eius usque ad diem nonum, donec sedetur apostema.	 If a warm assistant was injured then you leave the restoration of his fracture until the next day until the assistant is settled.
Et non appropinques ei in die tertio, et quarto omnino, nam tu faceres ei accidere accidentia mala.	 And do not come close to him on the third or fourth day since you will bring bad luck upon him.
Si autem os fractum est eminens super cutem detectum: tunc oportet, ut coneris reducere ipsum, et aequare ipsum manibus tuis cum facilitate et extensione parua.	 If the nose is broken and protruding above the wound then you must bring it down quickly using your hands in a similar fashion as we did; but if you are unable to reach it.
Si autem non praeparatur extensio eius, et ipsius aequatio manibus tuis: tunc reduc ipsum cum isto instrumento.	 If extension is not available for him and his equalization of hands then bring it down with this instrument.
Et est instrumentum quod fit ex ferro, cuius longitudo est quantitas septem digitorum, aut octo: et eius latitudo est secundum quantitatem uulneris.	 The instrument is made of iron and its length is the number of seven or eight fingers; and its width is according to the amount of blood from the wound.
Et propter illud necesse est medico, ut accipiat ex eis tria, aut quatuor secundum quantitatem qua indiget ad illud ex curatione in omni specie fracturae.	 Therefore a physician is necessary so that he may receive three, or four portions of the treatment according to the quantity needed for healing all wounds and fractures
Et sit rotundum: et sit in eo grossitudo parua, ut non duplicetur apud compressionem super ipsum in hora operationis: et sit acutae extremitatis, cui sit margo in extremitatibus suis.	 And it should be round, and there should not be excess fat on top of him during the period when he is being pressed down for an operation to take place: and there should also be a sharp edge where the thumb meets the palm of his hand.
Et sit superius eius ad grossitudinem ex medietate eius usque ad inferiora.	 And it must extend from his top (forearm) all the way down to its bottom part, including the middle part between them.
Et haec est forma eius.	 This is its shape.
Oportet in Hac Operatione, ut ponatur extremitas eius acuta curuata super extremitatem ossis eminentis: et impelle ipsum cum eo uice una, donec quando redit os et aequatur quadam aequatione.	 It is suitable for this operation so that he may place the sharp edge of his hand on the prominent thumb and then grip it with one hand as tightly as possible until after returning its mouth to an equal state or position (i.e., when all the bones are in their proper alignment)
Conare ergo aequare extremitates fracturae adinuicem.	 Therefore, bring both broken limbs into equal positions
Quod si extremitates eius fracta est subtilis, et non accipit eam instrumentum accaeptione bona, tunc opotet, ut incidas extremitatem illius ossis, donec instrumentum potestatem habeat eius.	 If the limbs of his broken arm are soft and cannot be easily held by him with a good grip, then he should try to strike it off with both hands until he has enough strength in each hand.
Si uero non potes reducere eos cum eo quod narrauimus omnino, tunc incide ipsum cum eo quod conuenit ei ex Incisoriis quae diximus: aut serra ipsum cum una serrarum quocunque modo possibile est tibi.	 Or if you cannot reduce them with him as we have said before, then strike it off with a blow from one side of the head using whatever technique is possible for you.
Deinde rade illud quod remanet in osse ex asperitate et corticibus minutis.	 Then leave what remains after striking it off in that manner on your bones and fingertips
Cum ergo reducitur os, et inuenit infirmus post reductionem eius dolorem uehementem laedentem, tunc scias, quod os non rediit ad locum suum naturalem.	 After you have reduced the arm, it is likely that the wounded man will experience great pain because his mouth cannot return to its original position or place
Fac ergo illud.	 Therefore do this.
Nam tu confers infirmo iuuamentum magnum, cum completur restauratio tua quam facis ossi.	 But if the injured man experiences a very great pain with your restoration technique, then you will complete his recovery as much as is possible using those techniques of yours.
Tunc submerge pannum in uino stiptico, nigro.	 Then plunge it into vinegar and black.
Et proprie si est in aestate.	 And if he is hot (warm).
Et non ponas super uulnus caerotum, neque aliquid in quo sit oleum: ut non faciat accidere in ipso putredinem et corruptionem.	 Do not place over the open wound any kind of fat or oil that may cause it to putrefy and become corrupted.
Deinde administra astellas in hora complementi tui a restauratione ossis.	 In the hour of your restoration, you will administer these remedies
Et dimitte uulnus detectum: ita, ut incidas cum forficibus foramen in inuolutionibus secundum quantitatem uulneris.	 Remove any blisters that have formed; so that with a knife you may cut through the membranes of the wounds according to their severity.
Et caue omni cautela, ne stringas uulnus cum fractura.	 Be extremely cautious not to tear the wounds while cutting them open.
Multotiens enim fecerunt istud stolidi medici: et fecerunt accidere super infirmos suos aut mortem, aut corrosionem, aut zuchem, id est, saniem.	 There are many mistakes made by those who have studied this art of medicine; they either killed their patients or themselves through a knife, death from injury, decay from disease - that is, insanity.
Et sit strictura tua mollis, lenis, diuersa stricturae fracturarum reliquarum.	 Your restriction must be soft and mild, varying according to the nature of fractures; so you must not force a fracture when it has already occurred
Quod si uulnus est malum, aut est uulnus magnum, et times super ipsum quaedam accidentia mala quae narrauimus, et inuenis dolorem in loco suspensum: tunc non oportet, ut ponas super ipsum astellas.	 If the wound is bad or great, and certain accidents have occurred over it, we suffer pain; then you must not place those remedies upon it, lest you cause more pain.
Et fac eis inuolutiones ex pannis duris in loco astellarum, et stringe ipsum cum eis.	 And make cuts through hard skins at the places of the remedies and tie them up with it.
Cum autem est post diem unum, aut dies duos, et uides uulnus iam incipere, ut in eo generetur pus: tunc aufer desuper ipsum pannum quem posuisti super ipsum cum uino.	 But if there has been one day or two days and the wounds have already begun to form; then you must wash away that skin over which you placed those remedies with vinegar.
Deinde administra licinia, et unguenta cum quibus de consuetudine nostra est, ut medicemur uulnera: sicut unguentum tetrapharmacon, et similia illi.	 Then administer the ointments and unguents as per our custom; just like the tetrapharmacopoeia ointment, and others of that sort.
Et conuenit tibi, ut soluas ligamentum.	 And it should be sufficient for you to have one bandage.
Et considera uulnus in omni die mane et uespere, donec consolidetur, et sanetur.	 Consider the wounds every day and often throughout the night until they heal.
Et oportet, ut praeparetur membrum taliter, ut currat ex eo pus ad inferiora cum facilitate.	 And you must stretch out that member as if it is about to come away from its own weight with ease.
Quod si praetereunt uulneri dies multi, et non consolidatur, neque abscinditur pus ab eo: tunc scias, quod illic sunt satagie ossis parua.	 If several days have passed and it has not been healed; do not let the pus come away from it at all; then you know that those bones are small.
Quare oportet, ut inquiras uulnus cum tenta.	 Therefore, inquire about wounds with a probe.
Quot uero ex illis alsatagie sunt separata, remoue ea, et extrahe ipsa.	 If those bones are separated; remove them and extract them separately.
Et quae ex eis sunt non separata, et pungunt membrum, et faciunt accidere dolorem, conare incidere ea, et auferre ea omni modo quo possibile est tibi illud.	 And if they are not separated; they penetrate the member and cause pain while cutting through them, and wash away those remedies in every way that is possible for you to do so.
Quod si accidat uulneri zuchen, aut ekileten, id est, estiomenus, aut species alia corruptionis et putrefactionis: tunc oportet, ut opponas unicuique ex eis cum eo quod conuenit ei ex curatione, cuius praecessit narratio in capitulo suo.	 "When a man is suffering from the heat of fever or exhaustion, whether through injury or illness - that is to say, with exhaustion or species related to corruption and putrefaction - at this point you must seek someone who has previously cured him following his narrative in one of his chapters.
Et ex eo in quo oportet ut stet sermo meus, et cui facias praesentem mentem tuam quando frangitur os, et eminet super membrum, sicut os coxae, et adiutorii, et similia eis ex membris magnis, est, ut non praesumas attractionem eius, multotiens enim accidit ex illo mors, imo dimitte ipsum, donec putrefiat.	 "From that person who is needed to keep me speaking when my face is broken and I am bleeding from the mouth, like a horse's nose, and of advisors, and similar things coming out through large openings in his body, it is necessary that you do not deceive him by giving him your present mind once he has been injured or sick, for many times death comes to him from this condition. Therefore, let them remove him until he decays.
Fortasse enim cadet per se post uiginti dies, aut triginta.	 "Certainly no more than 21 days
Tunc ergo cura uulnus, si uidetur tibi: et sinon, dimitte ipsum.	 "Therefore, when you see to your injury and otherwise let him go.
¶ De curatione Nodationis in uestigio fracturae.	 "Concerning the cure of a fractured nose
Caput XXI.	 "Chapter Twenty-one
Multoties accidit haec Nodatio in uestigio sanationis fracturae.	 "These treatments for injuries have often led to death.
Praecipue, quae est prope iuncturas: et foedatur ex ea figura membri.	 "Specifically those which are related to the face and arms:
Et fortasse prohibet membrum ab operatione sua naturali.	 "And in some cases they forbid operating on a natural member.
Considera ergo tunc, si nodatio est recens: administra in ea medicinas quae stipticitatem habent, sicut aloe, et olibanum, et myrrha, et sarcocolla, et acacia, et similia eis.	 "Therefore consider at this point if the nosebleed is severe:
Ita, ut accipias ex istis quasdam, aut omnes eas: et confice eas cum uino stiptico, aut cum albumine oui, aut cum aceto: et pone eas super nodationem in stuppa, et stringe eas super ipsam strictura bona.	 "And if you apply these bandages with wine or egg white or vinegar, and tie them on top of the nosebleed, and hold them tight at a good place.
Et dimitte stricturam, nec soluas eam diebus multis.	 "Do not keep the bandage for more than many days
Deinde solue eam, et itera aliam, donec remoueatur nodatio.	 "Until the bleeding stops.
Aut stringe super ipsam laminam plumbi decenter.	 "Or tie them with a cloth soaked in water.
Plumbo enim est proprietas remouendi omne quod timetur ex membris.	 "Water is the property of all that are afraid to leave their bodies.
Si autem nodatio iam in lapidem conuersa est, et stricta est, et festine prouocat necessitas ad auferendum eam: tunc finde super eam ex superiori parte eius, et incide superfluitatem eminentem: aut rade eam cum quibusdam rasoriis, donec remoueatur: et cura ipsam, donec sanetur.	 "If a nosebleed is already hidden by a hand or is very tight and the need to remove it has become pressing due to its harshness:
¶ De curatione quando restauratur, et remanet membrum post illud subtile, non secundum naturam suam.	 After cleansing when restored, and remove the membrane after that in a subtle way, not according to its own nature
Caput XXII.	 Head II
Quando restauratur fractura ossis, et remanet membrum post illud subtile, debile: tunc non fit illud nisi propter caussas multas.	 When the restoration of a fracture in the bones occurs, and remove the membrane after that in a subtle way, weak: then it does not occur except due to many causes.
Quarum una est, multitudo solutionis ligamenti et ligationis eius non secundum quod oportet: aut propter superfluitatem stricturae ligamentorum, donec prohibeatur nutrimentum currere ad membrum: aut propter multitudinem embrocationis superfluae in non sua hora: aut propter paucitatem sanguinis in corpore infirmi, et debilitatem eius.	 One of the many solutions is ligature and its ligation does not according to what should happen; either due to excess tightness of ligaments or prevent the flow of nourishment towards the membrane after excessive lubrication of the skin: or due to a lack of blood in the body weakness, and its weakness.
Et curatio illius est, cibare infirmum, et tenerum facere corpus eius, donec multiplicetur sanguis in eo.	 And the care of this is to feed the weak one, and make his body firm until more blood occurs there.
Et administra balneum.	 And apply a poultice
Et intromitte gaudium et laeticiam super eum.	 And pour over joy and gladness on him.
Deinde pone picem super membrum: ut attrahat pix ad ipsum nutrimentum multum.	 After that, put a piece of paper over the membrane to attract much food towards it.
Et assiduet embrocationem eius cum aqua tepida, donec currat nutrimentum, et redeat ad figuram suam naturalem.	 And with warm water he applies lubrication frequently until he gets nourishment and recovers his natural shape.
¶ De curatione ossium fractorum quando restaurantur tortuose.	 When the restoration of a fracture in the bones occurs broken
Caput XXIII.	 Head XXIII
Quando accidit membro iam restaurato post sanationem eius tortuositas, et eminentia ossi fracto, aut nodatio: et foedatur per illud forma membri, uerumtamen membrum non prohibetur ab operatione sua naturali: tunc non oportet ut recipias sermonem eius, qui existimat, ut frangatur membrum denuo.	 When the broken member is already restored after the cleansing of it, its tortuosity and prominence in a fractured bone occur at once, or perhaps it becomes numb: so that you are forced to use this form for both members, but do not allow the membrane itself by its own operation to be done away with; then it is not necessary that you receive speech from him who knows how to break it free.
Et iam fuerunt multi stolidorum medicorum et restauratorum, qui fecerunt illud in terra nostra.	 And many doctors and restorers have done this here on our land.
Et haec quidem operatio est uituperabilis ualde, perducens ad mortem, uel timorem magnum, ut scilicet sit mortalis.	 This operation is truly unbearable in its pain or fear of death, so that it may be called deadly.
Verum si claudicatio et nodatio sunt recentes: tunc oportet, ut embrocetur cum aqua tepida, in qua decoctae sint herbae mollificantes, sicut folia alteae, et radix eius, et mellilotum, et illis similia.	 If the numbness and weakness are recent; then it is necessary that he be lubricated with warm water in which have been soaked various soothing herbs such as elder leaves, root, mallow, and others similar to them.
Et fiat ei emplastrum cum emplastro mollificatiuo, sicut dyachilon decenter factum.	 Let him have a bandage softened with oil as if it had been made into a honeycomb
Aut sumatur mucilago radicis alteae, et concutiatur cum adipe gallinae, aut oleo sisamino: et emplastretur cum eo.	 A mixture of radish juice and honey should be applied to the affected area, or else grease from birds' fat can be used instead; after it has been softened, then bandage him with that
Aut sumantur ficus pingues, et terantur cum fimo columbino, et similibus eis quae nominantur ex medicinis diminuentes consolidationem.	 A mixture of elderberries and wax should be applied to the affected area; or else grease from bees' fat can be used instead; after it has been softened, then bandage him with that
Et quandoque soluitur nodatio cum fricatione assidua, antiqua, et leni, quae fit cum manibus humidis.	 Sometimes when there is a continuous, strong, and relaxed friction between the hands of one or both patients, it can be relieved by applying a mixture of elderberries and wax to that area; alternatively, grease from bees' fat can also be used instead after it has been softened
Et administretur motus membri ad omnem partem in horis omnibus.	 The motions of the members should go all around the whole body at once
Si autem tortuositas iam antecessit, et fortis facta est, et conuersa est in lapidem, et prouocata est necessitas ad curatonem eius cum ferro: tunc oportet, ut secetur superius eius, et soluatur continuatio ossis, et incidatur quod superfluit ex nodatione aut osse cum Incisoriis subtilibus: et administretur facilitas in illo cum sollicitudine et studio.	 If the tortuousness has already been done and is strong, causing a sharp pain when it strikes against stone; then let him be relieved by putting out the superior part of his wounds with iron; he should keep on pouring water over them until it subsides or is no longer necessary, after which the superfluous portion from friction or bone with fine incisions may be removed: thereafter, application of ease and diligence will follow.
¶ De sermone in Dislocatione.	 Of a dislocation of a limb.
Caput XXIIII.	 Chapter twenty four
Dislocatio est exitus alicuius iuncturarum a loco suo.	 A dislocation is the separation at a joint's place.
Quare prohibetur a motu suo, et foedatur figura membri.	 Because of his own motion it is prohibited to move him; and the form of the member becomes deformed.
Et facit accidere super infirmum dolores, et laesiones uehementes.	 And he brings about sharp pain and useless wounds because of that.
Quando ergo accidit alicui dislocatio, tunc oportet festinare ad restaurationem eius: neque tardet eam omnino.	 Therefore when a dislocation happens, then it is necessary to hurry up for the restoration of him; do not delay at all.
Nam si tardatur, apostematur locus, et fortasse cum eo reductio dislocationis.	 If he is delayed, then the place may become broken off or reduced in the dislocation itself
Propter illud ergo non oportet, ut moueatur, neque extendatur in hora apostemationis eius.	 Therefore it should not be moved, nor should an extension take place at that time of his delay; because of this.
Quoniam multotiens facit accidere spasmum, et dolores laedentes.	 Because he causes a lot to hurt spasms and suffering wounds.
Verum quando accidit illud, tunc oportet, ut properes ad phlebotomiam infirmi.	 Indeed when that happens then it is necessary to hurry up for the taking away of his pain from an illness.
Deinde dimittatur, donec quiescat apostema.	 Therefore it is removed, until he be silent
Deinde embrocetur membrum cum aqua calida et oleo.	 Then apply ointment on the member with warm water and oil
Deinde reducatur cum facilitate.	 And then reduced with ease.
Et curetur omne membrum cum eo cuius rememoratio ueniet in loco suo.	 And all the members, where its memory is not in place
Ego quidem iam ordinaui capitula dislocationis, etiam secundum quod praecessit in fractura, a superiori parte corporis usque ad inferiorem eius.	 I have already ordered the dislocations of the arms and legs as well as those that preceded them on fracture; from the upper part of his body to the lower one down.
¶ De cura dislocationis Mandibulae inferioris.	 For the treatment of dislocations of the lower arm.
Caput XXV.	 Chapter 25
Parum dislocantur duae Mandibulae nisi raro.	 Only two of the arms are dislocated, rarely.
Et dislocatio ambarum fit secundum unum duoru modorum.	 And both dislocations occur according to one way.
Aut enim remouentur a locis suis remotione parua, et mollificantur parumper.	 Either they are moved from their own places by means of some violence or become softened through gentleness.
Aut dislocantur dislocatione integra, completa, donec mollificentur ad partem pectoris, donec currat saliua infirmi, et non possit tenere eam, neque possit claudere os suum, et inuoluatur lingua eius cum sermone.	 Either the dislocated arm is made to be complete and unbroken as it was before until it becomes softened up towards the chest, down to its course of descent from the shoulder, until it cannot hold her any longer, nor can it be bent back against the mouth with speech.
Quando autem dislocatio eius est parua, tunc redit in pluribus dispositionibus per se cum paucitate.	 When the dislocation is small then he returns to many positions by himself with a few.
Si uero est dislocatio completa, integra: tunc oportet, ut administretur reductio eius uelociter, et non tardetur penitus: et est, ut teneat minister caput infirmi: et intromittat medicus pollicem manus suae unius in radicem Mandibulae dislocationis inter os eius, si dislocatio est a parte una.	 If the dislocation is complete and unbroken then it is necessary to bring about either the reduction of him immediately or delayed by pain; he must make effort to hold on with his hand towards its base which goes through the arm's dislocation; in case that it has been dislocated from one part
Aut intromittat duos pollices suos simul, si dislocatio est a duabus partibus.	 Or he may introduce both hands simultaneously if the dislocation is from two places.
Et reliqui digiti manuum eius sint extra, quibus aequet.	 And the rest of his fingers are outside which equalise
Et praecipe infirmo, ut mundificet Mandibulas suas, et absoluat eas ad manducandum ad omnem partem.	 Then apply a gentle force until he straightens out both arms and frees them for use throughout the body.
Et medicus aequet Mandibulam, et impellat Mandibulam, donec redeat ad locum suum.	 And the physician equalises one arm with gentle force and pushes it until he reaches his own place.
Quod si difficilis sit reductio eius, praecipue si sunt ambae Mandibulae simul: tunc administra uaporationem cum aqua calida, et oleo, donec fiat facilis reductio ambarum: neque tardes reductionem ambarum omnino, sicut diximus.	 If the reduction is difficult especially if both arms are dislocated simultaneously then administer an enema with warm water and oil until a simple reduction of both occurs; do not delay the reduction of both at all unless otherwise instructed.
Cum ergo redeunt et aequantur, et clauditur os infirmi, et non mollificantur: tunc pone super eas puluillos pannorum, cum ceroto quod sit factum ex cera: et oleo rosato.	 When this has happened and they become equalized, the jaw is loosened up but does not relax; then there comes a turn of the pliers above the gums, when he strikes it with the oil of roses.
Deinde ligetur cum facilitate cum ligamentis mollibus.	 Then it is tightened using soft ligaments.
Et sit somnus infirmi super dorsum suum: et caput eius sit stans inter duo puluinaria, ut non moueat ipsum ad dextram et sinistram: neque conetur, uel cogatur masticare aliquid: imo ponatur cibus eius sorbitio lenis, donec quando remouentur dolores, et nodatur Mandibula: tunc comedat quod uult, et administretur illud cum facilitate.	 Then the jaw falls asleep on its back; and his head is held between two pulleys so that it does not move to one side or the other; nor can it chew anything. So he puts food into his mouth gently with a spoon until the pains subside, then the mandible loosens up.
Non laboret super operationem oris sui apud comestionem et potum, et oscitationem, donec nodetur Mandibula, et sanetur.	 The jaw does not work properly during eating and drinking; until it is loosened, then it can function normally again.
Quod si difficilis fiat reductio duarum Mandibuiarum, quando dislocantur in hora aliqua, et non conuertuntur ad loca sua: tunc multotiens accidunt inde febres, et soda assidua: et fortasse soluitur uenter infirmi, et fortasse uomit choleram puram.	 When the reduction of the jaws is difficult due to their being dislocated at a certain time and they do not return to their normal positions; then many times fevers occur, and often one is seized by an excess of cold or heat; so it may be necessary for the nurse to soothe him with hot water.
Cum ergo uides illud: tunc scias, quia est perditio, et multotiens moritur ille cui accidit illud in decem diebus.	 When you know that this has happened, then you realize it is a loss; and many times he dies to whom this occurs within ten days.
¶ De reducione dislocationis Furculae, et extremitatis humeri.	 Of the reduction of dislocations in the elbow joint
Caput XXVI.	 Twenty-sixth part
Furcula quidem non dislocatur ex latere intrinseco, propter continuationem suam cum pectore.	 The furcula is not dislocated by the lower arm's natural movement, due to its own persistence around the breastbone.
Et dislocatur quandoque ad exteriora: et declaratur illud sensui.	 And it can be dislocated on occasion towards the outside; and this fact is declared through inspection of the body.
Et restauratio eius est, ut iaceat infirmus super dorsum suum, et extendat brachia sua.	 Its restoration occurs so that he may lie comfortably upon his back, and he extends his arms.
Deinde coarta locum cum palma tua coartatione forti, nam ipsa redibit.	 Then the heart's place is filled with a strong hand squeezing it, as it will be restored.
Deinde pone super ipsam emplastrum, et puluillos, et stringe eam.	 Then he places his hand over the chest and pulls on it strongly.
Extremitates uero eius quae sequuntur cubitum, et continuantur cum eo, non dislocantur, nisi raro.	 The limbs follow him closely as they move with him, not being dislocated except rarely.
Quod s dislocatur die aliquo: tunc oportet, ut reducatur et aequetur secundum quod diximus, et quod praeparatur tibi.	 "When one tooth is dislocated, then it should be reduced and restored to its original position as we have said, and what was prepared for you.
Deinde pone super ipsam emplastrum, et puluillos, et stricturam.	 Then put a plaster over the dislocated tooth, along with cotton wool and a strip of bandage.
Et praecipe infirmo, adhaerere tranquillitati et quieti, donec sanetur.	 And apply it gently, so that tranquility and peace may come to restore health.
Et cum hac eadem curatione reducitur extremitas Humeri, quando separatur etiam a loco suo.	 And with the same care, the extremity of the arm is reduced when it has been separated from its place as well.
¶ De reductione dislocationis Humeri.	 The reduction of a dislocated arm.
Caput XXVII.	 Head 27.
Scias, quod Humerus non dislocatur, nisi secundum tres modos.	 It is known that the humerus does not dislocate unless in three ways.
Quorum unus est, ut dislocetur ad partem titillici ad inferiora.	 The first way being dislocated towards the lower part of the titus.
Secundus est, ut dislocetur ad partem pectoris.	 The second is dislocated towards the chest part.
Et fortasse dislocatur ad superiorem partem Humeri: et illud fit raro.	 And sometimes it may be dislocated towards the higher part of the arm, which is rare.
Et non dislocatur ad posteriora, propter spatulam.	 It does not dislocate towards the back because of the presence of a bursa (fluid-filled sac).
Et non dislocatur ad anteriora, propter neruos.	 And it does not dislocate towards the front because of nerves.
Et plurimum quidem dislocatur et egreditur ad inferiora uersus titillicum: praecipue in illis, quorum carnes sunt paucae.	 It is most frequent to dislocate and reduce towards the lower part of the titus, especially those whose muscles are thin or weak.
Quoniam egrediur in eis uelociter, et ingreditur uelociter.	 Since reducing them quickly or slowly does not make any difference; they may be reduced just as easily when applied gently or firmly.
In illis autem quorum carnes sunt multae, est econtrario illius, scilicet quia egreditur cum difficultate, et ingreditur cum difficultate.	 However, in those whose muscles are many it is to the contrary of theirs since reduction with difficulty may occur for them and also because of reduction with difficulty occurs.
Et fortasse accidit quibusdam hominibus percussio, aut casus, et apostematur Humerus apostemate calido, et putatur propter illud, quia iam dislocatus est.	 And sometimes when the blow or fall strikes a man and he becomes disabled his arm is amputated close to its place because it had already dislocated.
Oportet ergo, ut experiaris illud, donec stes super certitudinem eius, et tunc procedas in curatione eius.	 Therefore you should proceed in caring for him until you are sure of his condition and then perform your care upon him.
Et cognoscitur dislocatio, quando est ad inferiora uersus titillicum: et distinguas inter Humerum dislocatum, et humerum sanum.	 It is known when the dislocation occurs towards the lower part of the titus and you must distinguish between the dislocated arm and the healthy one.
Nam tu inuenis inter eos diuersitatem manifestam, et inuenis in capite Humeri concauitatem, et sub titillico apud tactum caput humeri quasi ipsum sit ouum: et non potest infirmus reducere manum ad aurem suam, neque mouere eam omnibus motibus.	 In between these two extremes there exists a certain degree of difference; and you must apply this to the head of the human body, bringing its concavity into contact with your fingertips as if it were an object held in the hand: and he cannot be made weak so that his arm falls down upon his shoulder, nor can he move it about by all means.
Et similiter, si dislocatur uersus pectus, aut ad sursum: tunc inuenis manifestum tactum, neque occultatur.	 Similarly, if the jaw is dislocated or turned upwards; then you must apply your finger to it as before so that nothing may be hidden from view.
Et huius quidem dislocationis fit facilis reductio, quando est recens, aut infirmus est puer.	 This reduction can be made very easy when he is young, or is weak and feeble.
Et reductio eius est, ut eleuet minister manum suam ad superiora.	 His reduction is to lift up his hand above himself.
Deinde pone tu pollices tuos sub titillico eius, et eleua iuncturam cum fortitudine ad sursum ad locum suum: et minister eleuet manum suam, et extendat eam ad sursum.
